HEADLINE: The Listings: May 20-May 26

 BODY:
Selective listings by critics of The New York Times of new and noteworthy cultural events in the New York metropolitan region this week. * denotes a highly recommended film, concert, show or exhibition.

Theater

Approximate running times are in parentheses. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

Previews and Openings

'TERRORISM' Opens Monday. A jet black and ominous comedy about modern Russian life that weaves together six interconnected scenes set everywhere from an airport runway to a lover's bedroom. Written by the Siberian brothers Vladimir and Oleg Presnyakov (1:20). The Clurman Theater at Theater Row, 410 West 42nd Street, (212) 279-4200.

'SONGS FROM AN UNMADE BED' Opens Tuesday. Seventeen composers each wrote one song to go with the lyrics of Mark Campbell for this solo show about the heartaches and successes of a gay New Yorker. In repertory with ''Score'' (1:10). New York Theater Workshop, 79 East Fourth Street, (212) 239-6200.

'THE ARGUMENT' Opens Wednesday. Trouble in a relationship reaches its climax in this world premiere by Alexandra Gersten-Vassilaros, co-author of ''Omnium Gatherum'' (1:30). The Vineyard Theater, 108 East 15th Street, (212) 353-0303.

'THRILL ME: THE LEOPOLD & LOEB STORY' Opens Thursday.A musical based on the infamous 1920's murder inspired by the philosophy of Nietzsche. Sounds like a joke, but doesn't seem to be (1:30). The York Theater Company at the Theater at Saint Peter's, 619 Lexington Avenue, (212) 868-444.

'TABLOID CALIGULA' Previews start Tuesday. Opens Thursday. A comedy about a small-time criminal in the unforgiving underworld, part of the Brits Off Broadway festival (1:30). 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street (212) 279-4200.

'AFTER THE NIGHT AND THE MUSIC' Opens June 1. Elaine May's three one-acts is a new comedy on Broadway (remember those?) about married couples and aging singles looking for love. It's being called a play ''about life in the new millennium.'' Daniel Sullivan directs (2:00). Manhattan Theater Club, at the Biltmore Theater, 261 West 47th Street, (212)239-6200.

'B.F.E.' Opens May 31. A kooky Asian-American family tries to escape its stifling home life, while a serial killer stalks its neighborhood in Arizona (1:45). Playwrights Horizons, 416 West 42nd (212) 279-4200.

'THE CHERRY ORCHARD' Previews start Wednesday. Opens June 15. Is it a comic tragedy or a tragic comedy? Renew that old debate at Tom Donaghy's new adaptation of Chekhov's last play. (2:00). Atlantic Theater Company, 336 West 20th Street (212) 239-6200.

'DRUMSTRUCK' Opens late May/early June. The gimmick of this new spin on ''Stomp,'' which includes 11 percussionists from West and South Africa, is that every audience member plays his or her own drum during the show. David Warren directs (1:25). Dodgers Stages, 340 West 50th Street, (212) 239-6200.

'THE PARIS LETTER' Opens June 12. A repressed Wall Street investment banker (is there any other kind?) has a long, hard fall in Jon Robin Baitz's new drama that spans four decades (2:00). Roundabout Theater Company, at the Laura Pels Theater, 111 West 46th Street, (212) 719-1300.

'WORK' Opens May 28. Corporations take another beating in this satire of the cubicled life. Directed by Jim Simpson (1:30). Flea Theater, 41 White Street (212) 226-2407.

Broadway

'ALL SHOOK UP' In a pint-size theater with a campy young cast, ''All Shook Up'' might be a moderate hoot. Inflated to Broadway proportions, it's a mind-numbing holler (2:10). Palace Theater, 1564 Broadway, at 47th Street, (212)307-4100. (Ben Brantley)

'BROOKLYN THE MUSICAL' Try to imagine a sanitized ''Hair'' or a secular ''Godspell,'' with a helping of funky 70's disco, all filtered through the vocal pyrotechnics of ''American Idol'' (1:45). Gerald Schoenfeld Theater, 236 West 45th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)

'LA CAGE AUX FOLLES' Robert Goulet is now striding gallantly through this garish revival of the Jerry Herman-Harvey Fierstein musical. Although he is not too agile, Mr. Goulet brings a subdued professionalism to the role of Georges, the owner of a transvestite nightclub on the Riviera who is facing a rising souffle of domestic conflict (2:30). Marquis, 1535 Broadway, between 45th and 46th Streets, (212)307-4100. (Charles Isherwood)

'CHITTY CHITTY BANG BANG' The playthings are the thing in this lavish wind-up music box of a show: windmills, Rube Goldberg-like machines and the show's title character, a flying car. It's like spending two and a half hours in the Times Square branch of Toys ''R'' Us. (2.30). Hilton Theater, 213 West 42nd Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley)

'DIRTY ROTTEN SCOUNDRELS' On paper, this tale of two mismatched scam artists has an awful lot in common with ''The Producers.'' But if you are going to court comparison with giants, you had better be prepared to stand tall. ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels,'' starring John Lithgow and Nobert Leo Butz, never straightens out of a slouch (2:35). Imperial, 249 West 45th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)

* 'DOUBT, A PARABLE' (Pulitzer Prize, Best Play 2005). Set in the Bronx in 1964, this play by John Patrick Shanley is structured as a clash of wills and generations between Sister Aloysius (Cherry Jones), the head of a parochial school, and Father Flynn (Brian F. O'Byrne), the young priest who may or may not be too fond of the boys in his charge. The play's elements bring to mind those tidy topical melodramas that were once so popular. But Mr. Shanley makes subversive use of musty conventions (1:30). Walter Kerr, 219 West 48th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)

'FIDDLER ON THE ROOF' From the moment it sounds its first word in this placid revival, the voice of Harvey Fierstein (who has replaced Alfred Molina in the central role of Tevye) makes the audience prick up its ears. Whether it fits comfortably into the Russian village of Anatevka is another issue. But at least it brings a bit of zest to this abidingly bland production (2:55). Minskoff, 200 West 45th Street, (212)307-4100. (Brantley)

* 'GLENGARRY GLEN ROSS' Highly caffeinated bliss. Watching Joe Mantello's hopping revival of David Mamet's play about a dog-eat-dog real estate office is like having espresso pumped directly into your bloodstream. But what's a little lost sleep when you've had the chance to see a dream-team ensemble, including Liev Schrieber and Alan Alda, pitching fast-ball Mamet dialogue with such pure love for the athletics of acting (1:45)? Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, 242 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley)

'JACKIE MASON: FRESHLY SQUEEZED' Jackie Mason has so cunningly manufactured and marketed his dyspeptic comic persona -- the herky-jerky movements, the voice that's like a sinus infection with a bad back -- that he may soon be able to refine all actual jokes out of his act, and still slay 'em. That's chutzpah. And quite a talent, too (2:05). Hayes, 240 West 44th Street, (212)239-6200. (Isherwood)

'JULIUS CAESAR' Those cruel forces of history known as the dogs of war are chewing up everything in their path in this tragedy: friends, Romans, countrymen, blank verse and even the noblest movie star of them all. That's Denzel Washington, who plays the conflicted Brutus (2:40). Belasco, 111 West 44th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)

'LIGHT IN THE PIAZZA' Love is a many-flavored thing, from sugary to sour, in Adam Guettel and Craig Lucas's encouragingly ambitous and discouragingly unfulfilled new musical. The show soars only in the sweetly bitter songs performed by Victoria Clark, as an American abroad (2:15). Beaumont, Lincoln Center, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)

'MONTY PYTHON'S SPAMALOT' This staged re-creation of the mock-medieval movie ''Monty Python and the Holy Grail'' is basically a singing scrapbook for Python fans. Still, it seems safe to say that such a good time is being had by so many people that this fitful, eager celebration of inanity and irreverence will find a large and lucrative audience (2:20). Shubert, 225 West 44th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)

* 'ON GOLDEN POND' Placing a powerhouse like James Earl Jones in Ernest Thompson's teary sentimental comedy about an elderly couple's summer of healing suggests a German shepherd in a poodle-sized dog house. Yet rather than make his surroundings feel small and artificial in this surprisingly fresh revival, Mr. Jones's natural grandeur forces the play to find room for his sweeping emotional breadth (2:15). Cort, 138 West 48th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)

* 'THE PILLOWMAN' For all its darkness of plot and imagery, Martin McDonagh's tale of a suspected child murderer in a totalitarian state dazzles with a brightness now largely absent from Broadway. Exquisitely directed and designed, ''The Pillowman'' features top-of-the-line performances from Billy Crudup, Jeff Goldblum, Zeljko Ivanek and Michael Stuhlbarg (2:40). Booth, 222 West 45th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)

'700 SUNDAYS' This one-man memoir of a play by Billy Crystal has been set up to suggest a night of home movies with a buddy from your high school days who is equal parts attention-grabbing showoff and softhearted sweetie pie. You would be hard-pressed to find a Broadway show with a more artfully calculated comfort factor (2:20). Broadhurst, 235 West 44th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)

'STEEL MAGNOLIAS' Despite an ensemble featuring high-profile veterans of stage, film and television, sitting through this portrait of friendship among Southern women, set in a beauty parlor in small-town Louisiana, is like watching nail polish dry (2:20). Lyceum, 149 West 45th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)

'SWEET CHARITY' This revival of the 1966 musical, directed by Walter Bobbie and choreographed by Wayne Cilento, never achieves more than a low-grade fever when what's wanted is that old steam heat. In the title role of the hopeful dance-hall hostess, the appealing but underequipped Christina Applegate is less a shopworn angel than a merry cherub (2:30). Al Hirschfeld Theater, 302 West 45th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)

* 'THE 25TH ANNUAL PUTNAM COUNTY SPELLING BEE' William Finn's score sounds plumper and more rewarding than it did Off Broadway, providing a sprinkling of sugar to complement the sass in Rachel Sheinkin's zinger-filled book. The performances are flawless. Gold stars all around. (1:45). Circle in the Square, 1633 Broadway, at 50th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Isherwood)

Off Broadway

'BEAST ON THE MOON' Richard Kalinoski's musty romantic drama depicts the fractious marriage of two survivors of the Armenian genocide. Larry Moss's production is respectable and effective, but the performances by Omar Metwally and Lena Georgas are exhaustingly busy (2:00). Century Center for the Performing Arts, 111 East 15th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Isherwood)

'CAPTAIN LOUIE' The York Theater is serving a charming, child-size slice of Broadway with Captain Louie, a one-hour musical based on the 1978 picture book ''The Trip'' by Ezra Jack Keats. A talented young cast performs music and lyrics by Stephen Schwartz, an Oscar and Grammy winner whose credits include ''Pocahontas,'' ''The Prince of Egypt'' and the current Broadway hit ''Wicked'' (1:00). The York Theater Company at the Theater at Saint Peter's, 619 Lexington Avenue, at East 54th Street, (212)868-4444. (Miriam Horn)

'DESSA ROSE' It's easy to admire Stephen Flaherty and Lynn Ahrens (''Ragtime'') for their belief in the humanist potential in musical theater. But their new show isn't likely to win many converts to the cause (2:30). Newhouse, Lincoln Center, (212)239-6200. (Isherwood)

'FLIGHT: THE RISE AND FALL OF CHARLES LINDBERGH' Garth Wingfield's droning bio-play transforms Charles Lindbergh's journey from tickertape hero to disgraced Nazi sympathizer into a sort of talking newspaper, minus op-ed pages, lively writing and the weather report. With Gregg Edelman playing the everyman pilot turned celebrity, and Brian D'Arcy James on hand to personify a series of slimy reporters (2:00). Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, (212) 279-4200. (Isherwood)

'HENRY FLAMETHROWA' John Belluso's timely drama about girl in a coma who may or may not heal the sick engages the issues raised during the Terri Schiavo media circus. It's a thought-provoking and ambitious play (starring Tim Daly) but unfortunately there's no characters in it you can believe in (1:30). Studio Dante, 257 West 29th Street, (212) 279-4200. (Jason Zinoman)

* 'HURLYBURLY' If you are going to inhabit a wasteland, you might as well be thoroughly wasted. That seems to be the first rule of survival for the characters who have been brought so vibrantly and unforgivingly to life in this smashing revival of David Rabe's 1984 play. But thanks to a terrific cast, theatergoers are likely to experience a heady buzz of excitement and clarity that any of the desperate characters onstage would kill for (3:15). 37 Arts, 450 West 37th Street, (212)307-4100. (Brantley)

'KING A' Het Laagland's variation on the legend of King Arthur for children features five energetic actors, 40 tiny chairs, several a cappella musical numbers, occasional swordplay and frequent inspiring affirmations. The show is inventive and full of physical energy but in the end may be a little too talky for its intended audience (1:20.) New Victory Theater, 209 West 42nd Street, (212)239-6200. (Anita Gates)

'THE MAIDS' It is no small feat to find the chill in Jean Genet's 1947 play about two maids who fantasize about killing their boss, but Jean Cocteau Repertory manages it. Credit an eye-opening performance by Amanda Jones as Solange, the dominant of the two maids (2:00). Bouwerie Lane Theater, 330 Bowery, at Bond and East Second Streets, (212)279-4200. (Neil Genzlinger)

'MEMORY HOUSE' Dianne Wiest's warm, engaging performance provides the juicy filling in Kathleen Tolan's play about a tense stand-off between a mother and her teenage daughter over their differing philosophies of life. As she bakes a pie -- from scratch, mind you -- Ms. Wiest performs the still more challenging feat of keeping our sympathies keenly attuned to the appealing emotional undercurrents in Ms. Tolan's slight but sensitively drawn two-hander (1:30). Playwrights Horizons, 416 West 42nd Street, (212) 279-4200. (Isherwood)

* 'ORSON'S SHADOW' Austin Pendleton's play, about a 1960 production of Ionesco's ''Rhinoceros'' directed by Orson Welles and starring Laurence Olivier, is a sharp-witted but tenderhearted backstage comedy about the thin skins, inflamed nerves and rampaging egos that are the customary side-effects when sensitivity meets success (2:00). Barrow Street Theater, 27 Barrow Street, Greenwich Village, (212)239-6200. (Isherwood)

* 'THE PASSION OF THE CRAWFORD' For his slight but still tasty new show, John Epperson has decided to allow his voiceless alter ego, Lypsinka, to commune intimately and at length with one of her spiritual forebears, Joan Crawford. The centerpiece is a pointed but never vicious re-creation, or rather an interpretation, of a live interview Crawford gave at Town Hall in 1973 (1:30). Zipper, 336 West 37th Street, (212)239-6200. (Isherwood)

'A PICASSO' Jeffrey Hatcher's play is a formulaic two-hander set in occupied Paris in 1941. Pablo Picasso (Dennis Boutsikaris) is brought in for interrogation by the severe Miss Fischer (Jill Eikenberry), who works for the German cultural ministry (1:10). City Center Stage II, 131 West 55th Street, (212)581-1212. (Isherwood)

'THE PULL OF NEGATIVE GRAVITY' A Welsh man with no seeming interest in politics gets badly injured in the Iraq war and discovers that returning home will not be so easy. In this bruising, intimate and overly familiar play, which is part of the Brits Off Broadway festival, Jonathan Lichtenstein beautifully portrays how the war destroyed one rural family (1:30). 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212)279-4200. ( Zinoman)

'SCORE' The subject of this one-man show is Leonard Bernstein and music, and the performer Tom Nelis, and the director, Anne Bogart, ''get'' Lenny -- now brilliant, now flamboyant, now superficial, now physically responding to recorded music (1:30). New York Theater Workshop, 79 East Fourth Street, East Village. (212) 239-6200. (Anne Midgette)

'SHE STOOPS TO CONQUER' The comedy, written more than two centuries ago by Oliver Goldsmith, doesn't have much to say today, and Charlotte Moore, the director of the Irish Repertory Theater's production, wisely doesn't try to pretend otherwise. Instead she lets the actors play with the audience, a restrained glee that is hard to peg at first but ultimately pays off with some great laughs (2:30). Irish Repertory Theater, 132 West 22nd Street, (212) 727-2737. (Genzlinger)

* 'SHOCKHEADED PETER' A gorgeous ''nasty picture book'' of a musical, in which badly behaved Victorian tots come to ghastly ends. Inspired by Heinrich Hoffmann's droll collection of grisly bedtime stories, ''Shockheaded Peter'' is both the silliest and most sinister show in town. It is also one of the smartest (1:40). Little Shubert Theater, 422 West 42nd Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)

* 'THOM PAIN (BASED ON NOTHING)' Is there such a thing as stand-up existentialism? If not, Will Eno has just invented it. Stand-up-style comic riffs and deadpan hipster banter keep interrupting the corrosively bleak narrative. Mr. Eno is a Samuel Beckett for the Jon Stewart generation (1:10). DR2 Theater, 103 East 15th Street, (212)239-6200. (Isherwood)

Off Off Broadway

'THE FALL' Through Kenneth Nowell's looking glass, Hamlet is reversed, and a daughter; Jill is driven mad by her mother's ghost. Was the mother's expected death natural or an act of murder by her father, who too quickly married her mother's sister? A strong cast and superb director, Kate Marks, manage a tone that teeters effectively between the tragic and the hilarious, and one is left unexpectedly shaken (1:40). Looking Glass Theater, 422 West 57th Street, (212)307-9467). (Honor Moore)

'PLANET BANANA' If you think women's gymnastics would be more interesting if performed in outfits from the Victoria's Secret catalog, then ''Planet Banana'' is the place for you. Featuring incongruous stunts, moderately difficult circus routines and a sketchy searching-for-love story, the show is as enjoyable as it is raucous (1:25). Ars Nova, 511 West 54th Street, (212)868-4444. (Genzlinger)

Long-Running Shows

'AVENUE Q' R-rated puppets give lively life lessons (2:10). Golden, 252 West 45th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)

'BEAUTY AND THE BEAST' Cartoon made flesh -- sort of (2:30). Lunt-Fontanne Theater, 205 West 46th Street , (212)307-4747. (Brantley)

'BLUE MAN GROUP' Conceptual art as family entertainment (1:45). Astor Place Theater, 434 Lafayette Street, (212)254-4370. (Brantley)

'CHICAGO' Irrefutable proof that crime pays (2:25). Ambassador, 219 West 49th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)

'HAIRSPRAY' Fizzy pop, cute kids, large man in a housedress (2:30). Neil Simon Theater, 250 West 52nd Street, (212)307-4100. (Brantley)

'THE LION KING' Disney on safari, where the big bucks roam (2:45). New Amsterdam Theater, 214 West 42nd Street, (212)307-4100. (Brantley)

'MAMMA MIA!' The jukebox that devoured Broadway (2:20). Cadillac Winter Garden Theater, 1634 Broadway, at 50th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)

'MOVIN' OUT' The miracle dance musical that makes Billy Joel cool (2:00). Richard Rodgers Theater, 226 West 46th Street, (212)307-4100. (Brantley)

'NAKED BOYS SINGING' That's who they are. That's what they do (1:05). Julia Miles Theater, 414 West 55th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Gates)

'THE PHANTOM OF THE OPERA' Who was that masked man, anyway? (2:30). Majestic Theater, 247 West 44th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)

'THE PRODUCERS' The ne plus ultra of showbiz scams (2:45). St. James Theater, 246 West 44th Street, (212)239-6200. (Brantley)

'RENT' East Village angst and love songs to die for (2:45). Nederlander Theater, 208 West 41st Street, (212)307-4100. (Brantley)

'STOMP' And the beat goes on (and on), with percussion unlimited (1:30). Orpheum Theater, Second Avenue at Eighth Street, (212)477-2477. (Brantley)

'WICKED' Oz revisited, with political corrections (2:45). Gershwin, 222 West 51st Street, (212)307-4100. (Brantley)

Last Chance

'LES BELLES SOEURS' There is a good John Waters movie hiding inside Michel Tremblay's all-female play. This likable comedy about a New England woman who wins a million trading stamps wants to be a farce but is just a collection of observations searching for a shape (1:30). Kraine Theater, 85 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212)330-8650, closing on Sunday. (Gates)

'CHANTECLER' A version of Edmond Rostand's fable about a rooster and his role in the cosmos bills itself as a family show, but it's pitched way over the heads of the age group that would most enjoy its colorful costumes. But Cory Einbinder, the director, manages to make a smattering of scenes memorable: a parade of mutant roosters; a ridiculous trio of toads (2:20). Teatro La Tea, at Clemente Soto Valez Cultural Center, 107 Suffolk Street, second floor, (212)353-3101, closing on Sunday. (Genzlinger)

'JAPANESE PLAYS FROM THE EARLY 20TH CENTURY' The sole reason to see this evening of three one-acts is the rare staging of "Paper Balloon," by Kunio Kishida, one of Japan's most important pre-World War II dramatists. The rest of the program is embarrassingly misconceived (2:00) . Common Basis Theater, 750 Eighth Avenue, room 500, (646)554-6557, closing on Sunday. (Jonathan Kalb)

'LITTLE WOMEN' Watching the production is rather like speed-reading Alcott's novel. And the cast members mostly bring to mind 1860's-themed editions of American Girl dolls (2:20). Virginia Theater, 245 West 52nd Street, (212)239-6200, closing on Sunday. (Brantley)

* 'LOVE/LIFE A LIFE IN SONG' The year's finest cabaret act has expanded into a brilliant 90-minute concert for the theater in which Brian Stokes Mitchell sustains a remarkable fusion of pop-jazz singing and theatrical expression. A must (1:30). Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont Theater, (212) 239-6200, closing on Monday. (Stephen Holden)

* 'NINE PARTS OF DESIRE' The voices are a study in contrasts: vivid and subdued, sophisticated and naive, seductive and standoffish. But they cohere to form a powerful collective portrait of suffering and endurance in Heather Raffo's impassioned theatrical documentary about the lives of contemporary Iraqi women (1:25). Manhattan Ensemble Theater, 55 Mercer Street, (212)239-6200, closing on Sunday. (Isherwood)

'THE PEOPLE NEXT DOOR' Henry Adam's play starts out as a humorous, trenchant fable on how fear of terrorism can distort individual lives, not to say nations, but something mysterious happens after intermission: it mutates into a sitcom. The actors Ronny Jhutti and Mark McDonnell are very much worth watching, though. Part of Brits Off Broadway (2:30). 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212)279-4200, closing on Sunday. (Andrea Stevens)

'THE PURSUIT OF PERSEPHONE' A musical inspired by F. Scott Fitzgerald's college romance with Ginevra King jams 26 songs into two and a half hours -- which feels even longer. The evening's most entertaining moments are the drag routines by the Triangle Club, a fraternity to which Fitzgerald belonged when he was at Princeton (2:30). Prospect Theater Company, at the Connelly Theater, 220 East Fourth Street, (212)352-3101, closing on Sunday. (Phoebe Hoban)

Movies

Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/movies.

'A LOT LIKE LOVE' (PG-13, 107 minutes) A film that isn't half bad and every so often is pretty good, filled with real sentiment, worked-through performances and a story textured enough to sometimes feel a lot like life. (Manohla Dargis)

'THE AMITYVILLE HORROR' (R, 89 minutes) Low-key creepy rather than outright scary, this remake of the soporific 1979 horror flick marks a modest improvement on the original. But this time don't get attached to the family dog. (Dargis)

'BORN INTO BROTHELS' (not rated, 85 minutes, in Bengali) A lovely documentary about children of prostitutes in Calcutta. (A.O. Scott)

'BROTHERS' (R, 113 minutes, in Danish) This gripping psychological drama is Susanne Bier's second film to examine events worthy of Greek tragedy through a contemporary therapeutic lens; wartime trauma and sibling rivalry collide. (Stephen Holden)

'CRASH' (R, 107 minutes) A gaggle of Los Angeles residents from various economic and ethnic backgrounds collide, sometimes literally, in the course of a hectic 36-hour period. Well-intentioned, impressively acted, but ultimately a speechy, ponderous melodrama of liberal superstition masquerading as realism. (Scott)

* 'ENRON: THE SMARTEST GUYS IN THE ROOM' (not rated, 110 minutes) This sober, informative chronicle of the biggest business scandal of the decade is almost indecently entertaining, in part because it offers some of the most satisfying movie villains in quite some time. Recommended for everyone except those likely to be in the Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling jury pools. (Scott)

* 'FEVER PITCH' (PG-13, 98 minutes) To watch this new, thoroughly winning if not especially good romantic comedy is to appreciate, yet again, that the great loves of our lives are rarely perfect. (Dargis)

* 'FUNNY HA HA' (not rated, 89 minutes) Twenty-somethings looking for love, direction and fulfilling work -- this smart, cheaply made first feature is low-key, note-perfect and sneakily artful. (Scott)

* 'THE HITCHHIKER'S GUIDE TO THE GALAXY' (PG, 103 minutes) In this hugely likable, long-awaited film of Douglas Adams's beloved book, the world comes to an end not just with a bang, but also with something of a shrug. Nicely directed with heart and sincerity by the newcomer Garth Jennings, the film features Martin Freeman, a sensational Sam Rockwell and some gloriously singing dolphins. (Dargis)

* 'THE HOLY GIRL' (not rated, 106 minutes; in Spanish) The Argentine director Lucrecia Martel's second feature is an oblique, feverish exploration of religious ecstasy and adolescent sexuality. Hard to classify, other than as a miraculous piece of filmmaking. (Scott)

'HOUSE OF D' (PG-13, 97 minutes) Robin Williams plays a wise and kindly mentally retarded janitor. Enough said. (Scott)

'HOUSE OF WAX' (R, 105 minutes) Not the depilatory sequel to ''Beauty Shop,'' but rather a remake of the 1953 Vincent Price creepshow, with Paris Hilton, Elisha Cuthbert and a bunch of guys menaced by maniacs in the Louisiana backwoods. Grisly and slow. (Scott)

'THE INTERPRETER' (PG-13, 123 minutes) A political thriller, both apolitical and unthrilling, notable for two accomplishments: turning the United Nations into a movie set, and, even more remarkably, giving Nicole Kidman the opportunity to embody the suffering of Africans everywhere. (Scott)

'JIMINY GLICK IN LALAWOOD' (R, 90 minutes) This frantic comic hodgepodge built around Martin Short's popular Comedy Central character is an intermittently funny free-for-all that suffers from attention deficit disorder. (Holden)

'KICKING AND SCREAMING' (PG, 90 minutes) A so-so family sports comedy with Will Ferrell acting goofy and Robert Duvall (as Mr. Ferrell's father and rival youth soccer coach) parodying his performance in ''The Great Santini.'' The story follows a venerable Hollywood formula: its lesson is that winning isn't everything, but of course once you learn this lesson you'll win big anyway. (Scott)

'KINGDOM OF HEAVEN' (R, 145 minutes) A plaintive period epic from Ridley Scott, starring Orlando Bloom, about the bloody orgies of piety known as the Crusades. The film proves yet again that it takes an actor as self-serious as Russell Crowe to carry the weight of Mr. Scott's ambitions; it also takes a story Mr. Scott himself can really believe in for the filmmaker to do the same. (Dargis)

'KING'S RANSOM' (PG-13, 97 minutes) The cinematic equivalent of trampled chewing gum on a subway platform. (Holden)

'KUNG FU HUSTLE' (R, 95 minutes, in Mandarin and Cantonese) This kinetic, exhausting, relentlessly entertaining film throws scraps of a half-century of international pop culture into a fast-whirling blender. (Scott)

'LADIES IN LAVENDER' (PG-13, 104 minutes) Two Dames of the British empire (Judi Dench and Maggie Smith) inhabit spinster sisters in Cornwall who nurse a handsome Polish violinist back to health in 1936. Amiably bogus. (Holden)

'LAYER CAKE' (R, 104 minutes) Directed by Matthew Vaughn, making a smoothly assured debut, and written by J.J. Connolly, this is the newest in British gangland entertainment and the tastiest in years. The star of this show is the very good British actor Daniel Craig, who slices through ''Layer Cake'' like a knife. (Dargis)

* 'LOOK AT ME' (PG-13, 110 minutes; in French) A delicious comedy, as tart as it is sweet, of ambition, miscommunication and egoism. Set in a Paris that seems to be populated entirely by artists and writers, the film affectionately tweaks the bad manners and complacency of France's intellectual elite. (Scott)

'MA MERE' (NC-17, 110 minutes, in French) Avid sensation seeking in this film is such a grim affair that after a short while, the spectacle of its aimless characters bending themselves out of shape in the pursuit of depravity mutates from titillating to pathetic to laughable. (Holden)

'MAD HOT BALLROOM' (PG, 105 minutes) This documentary follows fifth-graders from three very different New York City public schools as they prepare to compete in a ballroom dancing tournament. The sight of 10-year-olds trying to master the graceful, grown-up motions of the fox trot and the tango is charming, and the glimpses of their lives in and outside of school are fascinating, though unfortunately the film offers not much more than glimpses. (Scott)

'MINDHUNTERS' (R, 106 minutes) This thriller re-imagines Agatha Christie's ''Ten Little Indians'' as ''Eight Little Profilers'': a team of would-be F.B.I. agents, isolated at a training compound to solve a simulated crime, soon realize that a real serial killer walks among them. The film may find a cult audience among fans of schlock cinema seeking a giggle and a scream. (Dana Stevens)

'MONSTER-IN-LAW' (PG-13, 102 minutes) Jane Fonda finds a zany, good-natured verve in a dragon-lady caricature that mirrors a comedy so desperate to avoid offending that it runs in panic from every issue it brings up but refuses to address. (Holden)

* 'MYSTERIOUS SKIN' (not rated, 99 minutes) Gregg Araki, one-time bad-boy of the New Queer Cinema, has made a heartbreaking and surpassingly beautiful film out of Scott Heim's clear-eyed novel about two Kansas boys dealing with the consequences of their sexual abuse by a little league coach. Superb performances, especially Joseph Gordon-Levitt. (Scott)

'OLDBOY' (R, 118 minutes; in Korean) The latest in dubious pulp-fiction cool, ''Oldboy'' centers on a seemingly ordinary businessman, Dae-su (the terrific Choi Min-sik), who, after being mysteriously imprisoned, goes on an exhausting rampage, seeking answers and all manner of bloody revenge. (Dargis)

'PALINDROMES' (not rated, 100 minutes) The same backward and forward: dud. (Scott)

'SAHARA' (PG-13, 130 minutes) It may not be ''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' but this screen adaptation of Clive Cussler's sprawling African adventure yarn is a movie that keeps half a brain in its head while adopting the amused, cocky smirk of the Indiana Jones romps. (Holden)

'SIN CITY' (R, 126 minutes) Based on the comic book series of the same name by Frank Miller, this slavishly faithful screen adaptation tracks the ups and downs of tough guys and dolls. ''Sin City'' has been made with such scrupulous care and obvious love for its genre influences that it's a shame the movie is kind of a bore. (Dargis)

* 'STAR WARS III: REVENGE OF THE SITH' (PG-13, 142 minutes) George Lucas saved the best -- or at least one of the best -- for the end. Or for the middle. In any case, the saga is now complete, and has regained much of its original glory. (Scott)

* '3-IRON' (not rated, 87 minutes; in Korean) A pop fable of urban loneliness that showcases the Korean director Kim Ki-Duk's witty sense of form. It's a thoroughly modern movie with elements of silent film, a love story shot with horror-film techniques, and a charming blend of style and sentiment. (Scott)

* 'A TOUTE DE SUITE' (Not rated, 96 minutes; in French) This downbeat homage to the French New Wave is a small, nearly perfect film that follows the sad chain of events when a headstrong 19-year-old art student goes on the lam with a Moroccan bank robber. (Holden)

'WALK ON WATER' (Not rated, 104 minutes) The director Eytan Fox takes on the controversial subject of Israeli nationalism in the aftermath of the Holocaust. Despite an implausible climax, this movie's quiet intelligence sneaks up on you. (Stevens)

'XXX: STATE OF THE UNION' (PG-13, 94 minutes). A wildly silly action flick in which all that stand between the American people and the yoke of tyranny are big guns, bigger breasts, the thud-thud-thud of commercial rap and the multiplatform artist known as Ice Cube (ne O'Shea Jackson). (Dargis)

Film Series

'CELEBRATING THE BLACK VOICES WEEKEND' (Tomorrow and Sunday) Symphony Space is screening George C. Wolfe's ''Lackawanna Blues'' (2005), based on Ruben Santiago-Hudson's play about a boardinghouse matriarch (S. Epatha Merkerson), and Stanley Nelson's ''Soldiers Without Swords'' (1999), a history of black newspapers in America. Mr. Santiago-Hudson, Ms. Merkerson and Mr. Nelson will hold question-and-answer sessions after their films. Leonard Nimoy Thalia, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212)864-5400; $25. (Anita Gates)

'FIRST NATIONS/FIRST FEATURES' (Through Monday) The final days of the Museum of Modern Art's 25-film showcase of the first films of directors from indigenous cultures around the world. 11 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, (212)708-9400, $10, $8 for 65+, $6 for students. (Gates)

'ONCE UPON A TIME: SERGIO LEONE' (Through Sunday) A cold-blooded henchman and a nameless drifter? It must be Leone (1929-89), auteur of the so-called spaghetti western. BAM Cinematek continues its 10-day Leone tribute. Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Fort Greene, (718)636-4100; $10, $7 students and 65+, $6, Cinema Club Members. (Gates)

FRANCOIS OZON RETROSPECTIVE (Sunday through June 5) The Museum of the Moving Image is honoring Mr. Ozon, the genre-bending French director of ''Swimming Pool'' and ''Under the Sand.'' The event begins with screenings of ''Sitcom'' (1998), about a suburban family with a rat, and ''Criminal Lovers'' (1999), a sort of tabloid version of the Hansel and Gretel story, and closes with a personal appearance by Mr. Ozon. 35th Avenue at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens, (718)784-0077; museum admission, $10, $7.50, 65+ and students. (Gates)

PACIFIKA: NEW YORK HAWAIIAN FILM FESTIVAL (Today through Sunday) Hey, how many film festivals include hula and ukulele workshops? New York University's Tisch School and the Hawaii Cultural Foundation are presenting some 30 features, documentaries and shorts that reflect the cultural heritage of Hawaii and the Pacific Islands. Titles include ''Mauna Kea: Temple Under Siege'' and ''Polynesian Power: Islanders in Pro Football.'' Cantor Film Center, 36 East Eighth Street; Tisch Film and Television Theaters, 721 Broadway, (212)966-3378; $8 to $10. (Gates)

'SCREEN DECO' (Monday) Film Forum celebrates Art Deco Week with screenings of two highly designed 1930's films and 45-minute illustrated talks by Eric Myers and Howard Mandelbaum, authors of ''Screen Deco.'' Ralph Murphy's ''Top of the Town'' (1937) is about a luxury nightclub atop a skyscraper. Edmund Goulding's ''Reaching for the Moon'' (1930) is set on a grand ocean liner. 209 West Houston Street, South Village, (212)727-8110; $10, $5, children, members and 65+. (Gates)

JOHN SAYLES AND MAGGIE RENZI TRIBUTE (Tomorrow) Mr. Sayles and Ms. Renzi will appear in person at the Museum of the Moving Image to present screenings of two of their films and participate in panel discussions about political filmmaking and the role of women in the industry. The films are ''Matewan'' (1987), about a coal miners' strike, and ''City of Hope'' (1991), about politics, crime and corruption in New Jersey. 35th Avenue at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens, (718)784-0077; museum admission, $10. (Gates)

Pop

Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music.

* THE BLOOD BROTHERS (Tuesday) Screaming lyrics like ''We're scrapped valentines/We're tangerine rinds'' over pummeling, chaotic guitars, this visceral Seattle quintet finds that temperature at which panicky noise-punk explodes into emo shrapnel. 8 p.m., Spirit, 530 West 27th Street, www.spiritnewyork.com or www.ticketmaster.com, $12. (Laura Sinagra)

BOREDOMS (Wednesday) For almost two decades now, the Japanese noise group has been one of the best psychedelic rock bands in the world. Though its latest album doesn't touch its best, its live show always matches sonic exploration with stage charisma. 8 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212)533-2111, $20. (Sinagra)

* BRIGHT EYES, THE FAINT, MARS BLACK (Tomorrow through Wednesday) The Nebraskan singer-songwriter Conor Oberst is perhaps too jittery to resonate as a New Dylan to diehard fans of the Old Dylan. But his emphatic wisdom, political indignance and wine-soaked laments make him a contender for the best songwriter of his generation. These shows focus on music from the electronic rock half of his recent double-album. With goth-dance band The Faint and self-deprecating rapper Mars Black. 7:30 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, (212)353-1600, $25, sold out. (Sinagra)

KELLY CLARKSON (Tomorrow) Pulling a hit song from the jaws of assured post- ''American Idol'' obscurity, the amiable Kelly Clarkson wisely ditched light dance pop for attitudinous pop rock. The Max Martin-penned ''Since You Been Gone'' is the catchiest party song since ''Hey Ya.'' 1 p.m., Rumsey Playfield, Central Park, 72nd Street and Fifth Avenue, (212)307-7171, $37. (Sinagra)

COMMON (Monday and Tuesday) The Chicago rapper Common has at times deserved the stigma that attends the label ''conscious rap'' -- the assumption of preachiness and lackluster execution. On his new record, though, he meets the challenge of working with the fellow Midwesterner and current ''It'' producer Kanye West. 9 p.m., S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street, (212)243-4940, $30.(Sinagra)

* THE DECEMBERISTS (Thursday) The weight of the bandleader Colin Melloy's baroque songs about child queens, heartsick cold war spies and vengeful seafarers is lightened by his sweeping lovelorn sing-alongs. 9 p.m., Warsaw, 261 Driggs Avenue, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, (718)387-0505, $18. (Sinagra)

* DEERHOOF (Tomorrow and Sunday) This excitingly whimsical band harbors equal amounts affection for No Wave angularity, exuberant noise-pop, and outsider naif art like the Shaggs. Their latest release is an electronically augmented fractured fairy tale about a kidnapping milkman. 9 p.m., Northsix, 66 North Sixth Street, Brooklyn, (718)599-5103, $10 (Sinagra)

DR. JOHN: 'ALL BY HISSELF' (Tonight and tomorrow, and May 25-29) Dr. John is steeped in New Orleans barrelhouse piano, swampy bayou funk and the gris-gris mysticism that surrounds it. He has applied his cagey growl of a voice and florid piano playing to jazz standards and songs with a conscience. 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., except Wednesday and Thursday when shows are at 8 p.m., Au Bar, 41 East 58th Street, Manhattan, (212)308-9455, $50. (Jon Pareles)

THE EVENS (Tomorrow) The Evens is the new duo from Ian MacKaye, who will forever be followed (if not always loved) by fans of his pioneering previous bands Minor Threat and Fugazi; joined by Amy Farina, he lends his famous wail to casual (but not passionless) indie-rock songs. With Parts & Labor and others. 2 p.m., East River Amphitheater, East River Park, the Lower East Side, www.eastrivermusicproject.com, free. (Kelefa Sanneh)

FISCHERSPOONER (Thursday) The heavily conceptual art-world buzz and gallery extravaganzas of Fischerspooner didn't turn its electro ditties into hits; now the band is back on a more humble scale. After show party with the D.J. Andrew Andrew ($10). 9 p.m., Canal Room, 285 West Broadway, Chinatown, (212)941-8100, $22.50 in advance, $25 at the door. (Pareles)

JOSEPHINE FOSTER (Tonight) You might call Ms. Foster's eerie warbling old-fashioned, except that it evokes a scrambled past that exists only in her own vision: mountain songs that never were, spaced-out hybrids that never will be. She is to open for Akron/Family and the Angels of Light. 9 p.m., Northsix, 66 North Sixth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718)599-5103, $15. (Sanneh)

FOUNTAINS OF WAYNE, BEN KWELLER (Sunday) Still underappreciated even after 2002's fluke MTV smash ''Stacy's Mom,'' these 30-something songwriters continue to write clever, pure pop ditties and some of the smartest yuppie satire around. This show benefits the Sing for the Children Fund. The Brooklyn-based melodist Ben Kweller opens. 4 p.m., Rumsey Playfield, Central Park, 72nd Street and Fifth Avenue, $50 for concert-only, $150-$2500 for special VIP access. Information at www.singforthechildren.org. (Sinagra)

* GANG GANG DANCE (Thursday) This sly, angular local band recently released ''God's Money'' (The Social Registry), a beguiling album full of splintered post-punk rhythms that cohere around the dreamlike murmurs of Lizzi Bougatsos. With Bloodlines and Electroputas. 9 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212)533-2111, $15. (Sanneh)

GIPSY KINGS (Monday) Strumming half a dozen guitars, singing in a husky rasp and stamping their heels on the floor, this French pop group is to flamenco what Rice-a-Roni is to paella. Which is not to say that some of their international hits, like ''Bamboleo,'' aren't fiendishly catchy. 8 p.m., Radio City Music Hall, 1260 Avenue of the Americas, at 50th Street, (212) 247-4777, $39.50 to $79.50. (Pareles)

* GZA, C-RAYZ WALZ, J-LIVE, VAST AIRE (Monday) The most cerebral Wu Tang Clan member, GZA (aka ''Genius''), fronts a tour of rappers who idealize the East Coast's Golden Age of elite M.C.'s. That is, they pursue nuance over histrionics and hubris. 8 p.m., B.B. King Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 42nd Street, (212)997-4144, $18.50 in advance, $20. (Sinagra)

SOPHIE B. HAWKINS (Tuesday) Most famous for the gay-positive radio hit, ''Damn, I Wish I Was Your Lover'' on a 1992 album adorned with naked photos by David LaChappelle, the intriguingly gutsy Hawkins now plays the singer-songwriter circuit. 7 p.m., Living Room, 154 Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212)533-7235, $32 in advance, $35 at the door. (Sinagra)

HOT HOT HEAT (Tonight) In a fray of 80's revival bands with interchangeable frontmen, this Canadian outfit boasts the more memorable bounce of curlicued leader Steve Bays. Problem is, as evidenced by the petulant single ''Goodnight Goodnight,'' his relatively shallow vision and cloying choruses don't often justify the cocky posture and overwrought hiccups. 6:30 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, (212)353-1600, $20 in advance, $23 at the door. (Sinagra)

BILLY IDOL (Sunday and Monday) Those who played the faux-noir ''White Wedding'' at their weddings, or affected a sexy snarl for old times' sake during pop-punker Billy Idol's quick flicker on MTV's ''I Love the 80's'' can now dance with themselves and others as Idol reprises his radio hits. 8 p.m., Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, Upper West Side, (212)496-7070, $33.50 to $53.50. (Sinagra)

JIM & JENNIE AND THE PINETOPS (Monday) Unlike a lot of younger Alt-Country bands that nod to classic traditions, this Pennsylvania group actually plays accomplished bluegrass topped by high lonesome close-harmonic vocals. 7 p.m., Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, Lower East Side (212)260-4700, $10. (Sinagra)

KING GYPSY ROCKER MASSIVE (Sunday) Gogol Bordello's Eugene Hutz has done for Gypsy music what the Pogues did for Irish traditionals, fusing their dizzy catharsis with visceral punk scuzz. This event fills the entire Knitting Factory complex with musicians occupying points on the Balkan punk rock continuum. Performers include DJ Hutz, World Inferno Friendship Society Nervous Cabaret, and Slavic Soul Party. 7 p.m., Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212)219-3132, $15. (Sinagra)

CYNDI LAUPER, NATALIE MERCHANT, NELLIE MCKAY, SANDRA BERNHARD (Monday) This benefit concert for the family of the well-regarded and recently deceased music executive Theresa Brilli will feature a full set by the 80's new wave rocker Ms. Lauper, as well as guest appearances by the serious-minded singer-songwriter Ms. Merchant, the cabaret wunderkind Nellie McKay and others. 8 p.m., Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, (212)777-6800, $60. (Sinagra)

* LIGHTNING BOLT (Thursday) This noisy and exuberant two-piece makes a terrifying racket, using fuzzed-into-obliteration bass and galloping drums (with some screaming, too) to create half-abstract pieces that hint at everything from heavy metal to dance music. With Mutant Life Expectancy and others. 9 p.m., the Hook, 18 Commerce Street, near Columbia Street, Red Hook, Brooklyn, (718) 797-3007, $10. (Sanneh)

SARAH MCLACHLAN (Tuesday) Still singing with epic pop swoon about love, resolute ambivalence, and broadly conceived existential matters, the founder of Lilith Fair is thinking increasingly globally (e.g., last year's ''World on Fire'' single). 8 p.m., Madison Square Garden, 33rd Street and Seventh Avenue, (212)465-6741, $34.50 to $84.50. (Sinagra)

MONADE (Tomorrow and Sunday) Laetitia Sadier of the pacific, intellectual art pop group Stereolab continues in that vein with music that's charming yet somewhat insular. 9:30 p.m., Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, Lower East Side (212)260-4700, $14 in advance, $12 at the door. (Sinagra)

MARK O'CONNOR, DAVID BROMBERG, NATALIE MACMASTER (Tomorrow) Billed as a ''fiddling summit,'' this concert should put some idiosyncratic twists into tradition. It includes Mark O'Connor's mixture of Appalachian and classical music, Natalie MacMaster's rough-hewn Celtic fiddling and stepdancing from Cape Breton and David Bromberg's all-American eclecticism and vintage violins, along with Mr. Bromberg's guests Jay Ungar (whose ''Ashokan Farewell'' was the theme of Ken Burns's ''Civil War'') and Molly Mason. 8 p.m. New Jersey Performing Arts Center, One Center Street, Newark (888)466-5722, $10 to $48. (Pareles)

JOHN OSWALD AND MICHAEL SNOW (Monday) Early adopter of mashup pop bricolage, the ''Plunderphonics'' originator John Oswald plays saxophone with the avant-garde filmmaker/artist, and here pianist, Michael Snow. 9:30 p.m., Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, (212)358-7501, $10. (Sinagra)

PINBACK (Tuesday) Overthought pop constructions are an acquired taste, but this band's pointillist songs are at their most compelling when they sound like stripped-down sonic schematics. 8 p.m., Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, (212)777-6800, $18.50 in advance, $20 at the door. (Sinagra)

PLASTIC PEOPLE OF THE UNIVERSE (Sunday) In Prague in the 1960's, the Plastic People of the Universe transmuted the lessons of Frank Zappa and the Velvet Underground into dank, dissonant, precise songs that drew the wrath of Czechoslovakia's Communist government. The band's persecution galvanized a dissident movement that eventually triumphed. But the reconstituted band's songs are more than period pieces; by finding a rock language for Eastern European angst, they turn desperation inside out. 7 and 9:30 p.m., Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, (212)539-8777, $25 in advance, $30. (Pareles)

RILO KILEY, PORTASTATIC (Thursday) This band combines the expansive American longing of Bruce Springsteen with the bedroom introspection of early Liz Phair. The frontwoman Jennie Lewis's humanized star power makes for an explosive live show. The Superchunk leader Mac MacCaughan's long-standing side project Portastatic opens. 8 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, (212)353-1600, $18 in advance, $20. (Sinagra)

SNOW PATROL (Tonight) This lush, introspective British pop music about the mundane acrimonies of close romantic relationships appeals to fans of Coldplay and The Shins. 7:30 p.m., Roseland, 239 West 52nd Street, (212)777-6800, $23, sold out. (Sinagra)

TAJ MAHAL (Tuesday through Thursday) The fingerpicking, jazz-loving, globe-hopping yet down-home bluesman measures the persistence of the blues as he traces its kin. 8 p.m., Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212)475-8592, $30. (Pareles)

TEAM SLEEP (Wednesday) Though his band, the Deftones, got famous on the frat-friendly nu-metal circuit in the late 90's, Chino Moreno has a reputation as a thoughtful lyricist and eclectic music fan. He's been steadily taking things in a dreamier direction, and this side project looks to explore the expansive desertscapes beyond hard-rock bashing. 8 and 11 p.m., Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212)219-3132, $15 in advance, $17 at the door. (Sinagra)

THIEVERY CORPORATION (Tonight and tomorrow) Ten years ago this D.C. D.J. duo typified the ''Swingers'' era at its most laconic. Remarkably, they've persisted as a durable act, adroitly integrating various electronic and global strains through a dub sensibility. 8 p.m., Spirit, 530 West 27th Street, www.spiritnewyork.com or (212)307-7171, $35. (Sinagra)

TRACHTENBURG FAMILY SLIDE SHOW PLAYERS (Thursday) Continuing their familial performance art project, Jason Trachtenburg plays lo-fi pop tunes inspired by slides found at yard sales while wife Tina runs the projector. Their 9-year-old daughter Rachel, who has become something of an underground girl-power poster kid, plays drums. 8 p.m., Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, Lower East Side, (212)358-7503, $12. (Sinagra)

U2 (Tonight) After 2000's thrilling ''All that You Can't Leave Behind'' (Interscope), the new ''How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb'' (Interscope) and the ''Vertigo'' tour itself focus on what humans can live without: namely ICBM's and, evidently, some of U2's more shopworn live staples. Hence the vivid resurrection of decades-old rarities like ''Electric Co.'' 8 p.m., Madison Square Garden, 33rd Street and Seventh Avenue, Manhattan, (212)465-6741, $54 to $169, sold out. (Sinagra)

* WORLD MUSIC INSTITUTE 20TH ANNIVERSARY BENEFIT CONCERT (Tomorrow) Traditionalists turn eclectic as the tabla master Zakir Hussain gathers percussionists, flutists and string players with expertise in everything from Irish reels to flamenco, Moroccan gnawa music to raga, African polyphony to Chinese pipa (lute) tone poems. 8 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212)840-2824 or (212)545-7536, $30 to $100. (Pareles)

Cabaret

Full reviews of recent cabaret shows: nytimes.com/music.

* KAREN AKERS (Tuesdays through Saturdays) Classic romantic ballads gracefully rendered by a statue come to life. Oak Room, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, Manhattan, (212)419-9331, through May 28. Tuesdays through Thursdays at 9 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays at 9 and 11:30 p.m. Cover is $50; a $50 prixe fixe dinner is required Thursdays through Saturdays at 9; otherwise, a $20 minimum. (Stephen Holden)

DEBBY BOONE (Tonight and tomorrow) The squeaky clean voice behind ''You Light Up My Life'' pays bland but heartfelt tribute to her mother-in-law, Rosemary Clooney. 8 and 11 p.m., Feinstein's at the Regency, 540 Park Avenue, at 61st Street, (212)339-4095, $60 cover, $40 minimum. (Holden)

BARBARA CARROLL (Sunday at 2 p.m.) Even when swinging out, this Lady of a Thousand Songs remains an impressionist with special affinities for Thelonious Monk and bossa nova. Oak Room (see above). Cover: $55, including brunch at noon. (Holden)

* BARBARA COOK (Tuesdays through Saturdays) Now 77, the great lyric soprano pays tribute to her longtime musical director Wally Harper, who died last October, and other friends who are gone. Ms. Cook's performances are master classes in life as well as in singing. Cafe Carlyle, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, (212)744-1600, through May 27. Tuesdays through Fridays at 8:45 p.m.; Saturdays at 8:45 and 10:45 p.m. Cover is $75 Tuesdays through Thursdays, $90 on Fridays and Saturdays. (Holden)

JULIE WILSON (Tonight and tomorrow) The 80-year-old queen mother of cabaret transforms songs into half-spoken dramatic monologues, some witty, others heartbreaking. 7 p.m., Helen's, 169 Eighth Avenue, near 18th Street, Chelsea, (212)206-0609, $25 cover, $15 minimum. (Holden)

Jazz

Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music.

GERALD CLEAVER AND VIOLET HOUR (Tonight) Mr. Cleaver, a drummer who's played in all bands all over the stylistic map, brings in his own ensemble, including the saxophonist J.D. Allen, the trumpeter Ralph Alessi, the pianist Ben Waltzer and the bassist Chris Lightcap. 9 p.m., Cornelia Street Cafe, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319, cover, $10. (Ben Ratliff)

LARRY CORYELL (Tonight) Having played in Mingus's band in the 1970's, the guitarist Larry Coryell is featured in a program of Mingus music. Part of the Lost Jazz Shrines series, celebrates old clubs and the figures who played there; in this case the club is the Village Gate. 8 p.m., preceded by a talk with Mr. Coryell at 7 p.m., TriBeCa Performing Arts Center, 199 Chambers Street, (212)220-1460, $25. (Ratliff)

DOMINIQUE EADE WITH BRAD SHEPIK (Thursday ) Ms. Eade is an exceptional singer with a wide vocal range and a grasp on the intricacies of style in of blues, soul, jazz and pop; here she appears in a duo with the guitarist Mr. Shepik. 8:30 p.m., Cornelia Street Cafe, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319, cover, $10. (Ratliff)

* BILL FRISELL TRIO (Tomorrow and Sunday) This group, with the keyboardist Sam Yahel and the drummer Brian Blade, is one of three different trios that the guitarist Bill Frisell now plays with, and it's the one that perhaps goes the furthest out there. 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., with an 11:30 p.m. set tomorrow night, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212)576-2232, cover, $30. (Ratliff)

* WYCLIFFE GORDON'S THE BIG FOUR (Tuesday through Sunday) The dynamic trombonist's new band, with the pianist Johnny O'Neal, the bassist Reginald Veal and the drummer Herlin Riley. 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., with an 11:30 set Fridays and Saturdays, Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola, Frederick P. Rose Hall, 60th Street and Broadway, Manhattan, (212)258-9800, $30, plus a $10 minimum (Ratliff)

ANDREW HILL 'RETRO' QUARTET (Through tomorrow) The pianist Andrew Hill is one of the most mysterious composers of modern jazz, not just for his fraught harmonies and layered rhythms but for his periodic disappearances from the scene. But he's come back over the last decade, leading a number of bands; this is a quartet with the saxophonist Greg Tardy, the bassist John Hebert and the drummer Leroi Jones. 9 and 11 p.m., Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, (212)581-3080, cover, $30, plus a $10 minimum. (Ratliff)

FRED HO AND THE AFRO-ASIAN ENSEMBLE (Tonight) A band that's been around for more than 20 years now, blending traditional Chinese music with jazz. 9 p.m., BAMCafe, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Fort Greene Brooklyn, (718) 636-4100,no cover, $10 minimum. (Ratliff)

* BOBBY HUTCHERSON QUARTET (Through Sunday) Mr. Hutcherson is one of the great individual voices and better composers in jazz, and he's a vibraphonist, making him triply rare. After 40 years, he still sounds current. The band includes the pianist Mike LeDonne, the bassist Dwayne Burno and the drummer Billy Drummond. 9 and 11 p.m., Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212)255-4037, cover, $30. (Ratliff)

VISION CLUB: LIFETIME VISIONS ORCHESTRA (Tomorrow night) A band led by the saxophonist Joseph Jarman, one of the founders of the Art Ensemble of Chicago, and the pianist and composer Chris Chalfant. It's a big, freewheeling, vamp-crazy band, with singing about peace and harmony. 9:30 p.m., Clemente Soto Velez Gallery, 107 Suffolk Street, Lower East Side; www.visionfestival.org, $15.(Ratliff)

JUNIOR MANCE (Through tomorrow) In his mid-70's, Mr. Mance is an excitable, physical player who throws himself into fast tempos and splashy, jubilant fancies that are not heard much outside Oscar Peterson. But he is also an earthy blues-and-bop player from Chicago; his resume includes time in the bands of Dinah Washington, Dizzy Gillespie and Cannonball Adderley. 8, 10, and midnight, Sweet Rhythm, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street, West Village, (212)255-3626, cover, $20, minimum, $10. (Ratliff)

KATE McGARRY (Tomorrow) A lot of jazz singers are good at a few devices and punch them out song after song; Ms. McGarry has a deeper supply. You'll find shades of pop singers like Suzanne Vega and Rickie Lee Jones in her voice; you'll also find some of the highest refinements of great jazz singing. She has a breadth of material that runs from jazz standards to traditional Irish ballads to a version of the Kinks' ''(So) Tired of Waiting for You.'' Her new record is ''Mercy Street'' (Palmetto). 6 p.m., 55 Bar, 55 Christopher Street, West Village, (212)929-9883, no cover (Ratliff)

BILL McHENRY TRIO (Tuesday) Like players decades ago, the tenor saxophonist Mr. McHenry puts his big, round sound before anything else; he likes playing slowly and choosing his moves, guided compositionally by Ornette Coleman and emotionally by Don Byas. 9 p.m., Nublu, 62 Avenue C, between Fourth and Fifth Streets, East Village, (212) 979-9925; www.nublu.net, cover, $5. (Ratliff)

* JOE LOVANO QUARTET (Through Sunday) It's the fascinating band from Mr. Lovano's last two albums, with the pianist Mulgrew Miller subbing for Hank Jones. They're playing Thad Jones pieces all week (there are some on Mr. Lovano's new album ''Joyous Encounter''), stylistically rolling the last 50 years of jazz history around. 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow night, Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola, Frederick P. Rose Hall, 60th Street and Broadway, 5th floor, Manhattan, (212)258-9800, cover, $30, plus a $10 minimum (Ratliff)

ONE FOR ALL (Through tomorrow) A kind of hard-bop repertory quartet including the trumpeter Jim Rotondi, the saxophonist Eric Alexander, the bassist Nat Reeves and the drummer Joe Farnsworth; both nights this weekend the pianist Harold Mabern will sit in. 9, 11 and 12:30, Smoke, 2751 Broadway at 106th Street, Manhattan, (212)864-6662, cover, $25. (Ratliff)

* EIVIND OPSVIK 'OVERSEAS' (Wednesday) Mr. Opsvik is a young Norwegian bassist and bandleader with an unusual gift for writing small, poignant pieces of music. His melodic shards are strong, as are the chord sequences moving underneath them; he has the distinction, in a time when jazz compositions are becoming increasingly opaque, of writing catchy tunes, and his fat-toned, unfussy bass sound enhances them. His new record is ''Overseas II,'' on Fresh Sound, and his band includes Tony Malaby, Jacob Sacks, Craig Taborn, and Kenny Wollesen. 10 p.m., 55 Bar, 55 Christopher Street, West Village, (212)929-9883, cover, $8 and a one-drink minimum (Ratliff)

OREGON (Through) Celtic music, jazz, swing and classical guitar get all mixed up in the music of Oregon, a band that's been around since 1970. The band rarely comes around anymore, and the lineup is as it has been, more or less, for ages: Ralph Towner on guitar, Paul McCandless on oboe, Glen Moore on bass, Mark Walker on drums. 8 and 10 p.m. with an 11:30 show tonight and tomorrow night, Iridium, 1650 Broadway at 51st Street, Midtown, (212)582-2121, cover, $30 tonight and Sunday, $32.50 tomorrow, with a $10 minimum all nights . (Ratliff)

* NICHOLAS PAYTON QUINTET (Wednesday through May 28) The trumpeter Nicholas Payton first grabbed the jazz world's attention with his remarkable feeling for early New Orleans jazz and more recently made an obstinately spacey funk record, but he's spent most of his professional time dealing with the rich languages of post-1960 jazz. Here he'll be mining that territory. 9 and 11, Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, midtown, (212)581-3080, cover, $30, with a $10 minimum (Ratliff)

ERIC REED TRIO (Through tomorrow) Always alert and fluent, Mr. Reed, the pianist, has gospel and bebop and a lot of post-50's modernism in him, too. He's a combination of assiduous writer, arranger and fast-thinking improviser, and he's working with a group this week that includes the bassist David Wang and the drummer Willie Jones. 8 and 9:45 p.m., Kitano Hotel, 66 Park Avenue at 38th Street, Manhattan, (212)885-7000, cover, $15, minimum, $10. (Ratliff)

WADADA LEO SMITH/LEROY JENKINS WORLD QUARTET (Tonight) A trumpeter and violinist, both genre-crossers and both elder figures from the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians, the co-operative organization for jazz improvised that started in Chicago and shifted its base to New York. 8 p.m., Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th Street, Manhattan, (212)594-7149, $20, students and 62+, $10. (Ratliff)

* LINCOLN CENTER ORCHESTRA PLAYS THAD JONES (Through tomorrow) The trumpeter and composer Thad Jones, who died in 1986, always deserves a second look. A member of Count Basie's orchestra during the 1950's and early 60's, he decamped to form his own big band, which played weekly shows at the Village Vanguard, starting a new large-ensemble jazz tradition. Jazz at Lincoln Center's gleaming band takes on his music, with the saxophonists Jerry Dodgion and Billy Harper and the bass trombonist Douglas Purviance, as guests; Vincent Gardner, one of Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra's trombonists, presents new arrangements of the old tunes. 8 p.m., Rose Theater, Frederick P. Rose Hall, 60th Street and Broadway, Manhattan, (212)721-6500, $85to $150. (Ratliff)

* CLARK TERRY (Tuesday through May 29) It's possible that no other jazz musician has as much amusing old-guy charm as Mr. Terry, and when you think he's all sweetness, he'll rattle you profoundly with a cool, beautifully executed piece of fluegelhorn playing. 9 and 11 p.m., Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212)255-4037, $30. (Ratliff)

THE TRIO/SEX MOB (Tonight) The Trio includes three jazz-oriented jam-band heroes: the bassist Chris Wood (of Medeski, Martin & Wood), the saxophonist Skerik (who plays with Stanton Moore and Galactic) and the drummer Johnny Vidacovich (of Astral Project). Sex Mob is rowdy quartet led by the slide-trumpeter Steven Bernstein, known to cover songs written by everyone from Wynton Marsalis to Nirvana; Mr. Bernstein is a gifted enough arranger to get the sarcasm-to-respect equation right, 10 p.m., Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7501, $20. (Ratliff)

Classical

Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music.

Opera

'CYRANO DE BERGERAC' (Tonight) Musically not much of an opera, it does provide a meaty role for the ageless tenor Placido Domingo, who gives a vocally fervent and poignant portrayal of Cyrano, the fearless and noble guardsman cursed with an absurdly huge nose. The cast is excellent, and Francesca Zambello has created a stylish and handsome production. 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212)362-6000, sold out, but returns may be available. (Anthony Tommasini)

'L'ELISIR D'AMORE' (Tomorrow and Sunday) Run on enthusiasm and a shoestring, the tiny Amato Opera mounts a modest production of the Donizetti classic. Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m., Sunday at 2:30 p.m., Amato Opera, 319 Bowery, at Second Street, East Village, (212)228-8200, $30, $25 for students and 65+.(Jeremy Eichler)

'FAUST' (Tomorrow) In a revelatory performance James Levine cuts through the hokum and captures the music's dignity and elegance. And the Met has assembled a top-rank cast, especially Rene Pape as Mephistopheles. Alas, the Met's new production by Andrei Serban is a jumble. 1:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212)362-6000, sold out, but returns may be available. (Tommasini)

'TOSCA' (Tomorrow) The Met puts its season to bed with a soothing old favorite: Puccini's classic, in Franco Zeffirelli's lavish and historically authentic production. The high point of the cast should be Marcello Giordani, who has been singing ardently and ringingly, as Cavaradossi. 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212)362-6000, $145 and $215 tickets remain. (Anne Midgette)

Classical Music

BARGEMUSIC (Tonight, tomorrow, Sunday and Thursday) Great views and typically fresh performances help make this floating concert hall one of the best for chamber music. Tonight brings Olga Vinokur, a pianist, in a program of Russian music. Tomorrow and Sunday, it's the American String Quartet, and Thursday, Roberto Prosseda, another pianist, plays Mendelssohn. Tonight, tomorrow and Thursday at 7:30; Sunday at 4 p.m. Fulton Ferry Landing next to the Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn, (718)624-2083, $35; tomorrow and Sunday $40. (Eichler)

CANTORI NEW YORK (Tomorrow) This chamber choir, directed by Mark Shapiro, sings with the virtuosity and assurance to carry off the kind of program it is offering here -- all new works, by Pascal Dusapin, Raphael Fusco and Richard Danielpour. 8 p.m., Society for Ethical Culture, Central Park West at 64th Street, (212)439-4758, $25, $15 for students and 65+. (Allan Kozinn)

ENSEMBLE INTERCONTEMPORAIN (Tuesday and Wednesday) Paris's estimable new-music laboratory comes to Lincoln Center's Rose Hall for two nights, the first offering Benedict Mason's ''ChaplinOperas'' led by Jonathan Nott, the second with music by Gyorgy Ligeti and Wolfgang Rihm. 8 p.m., Rose Theater, Broadway at 60th Street, (212)721-6500, $45 on Tuesday, $40 on Wednesday.(Bernard Holland)

GRAND RAPIDS SYMPHONY (Tomorrow) At 75, an orchestra looks to make a national name for itself. A good outing here, under its music director, David Lockington, could take care of that. 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212)247-7800, $24 to $75. (James R. Oestreich)

HARMONIE SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA AND ST. ANDREW CHORALE (Sunday) A celebration of the church's departing music minister includes performances of Gounod's ''St. Cecilia Mass'' and Saint-Saens's Third Symphony and ''Priere'' for cello and organ. 3 p.m., Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at 73rd Street, (212)288-8920, free. (Midgette)

JAMA JANDROKOVIC (Tonight) Give this soprano credit for putting herself on the line. Tonight she presents the premiere of ''Five Lovers,'' a song cycle in which her original poems, about a recently divorced woman trying to reinvent herself in New York, are set to music by Lori Laitman, Luna Pearl Woolf and Paul Moravec. 8 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212)721-6500, $20 to $40. (Tommasini)

LOCRIAN CHAMBER PLAYERS (Tonight) As a point of principle, this new-music ensemble plays only works that are less than 10 years old. Among its finds this time are scores by Osvaldo Golijov, Tom Johnson, Harrison Birtwistle, John Halle and Harold Meltzer. Riverside Church, 91 Claremont Avenue, at 121st Street, Morningside Heights, (718)458-4864, free. (Kozinn)

LYRIC CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY (Wednesday) This enterprising group presents its final program of the season, with works by Haydn, Stravinsky, Gershwin and Brahms (the trio for clarinet, cello and piano). The roster of performers features up-and-coming young artists, including the clarinetist Igor Begelman. 7:30 p.m., Kosciuszko Foundation, 15 East 65th Street, Manhattan, (212)279-4200, $45. (Tommasini)

NATIONAL CHORALE (Tonight) Beethoven's Ninth Symphony isn't enough for one evening? Well, here's Poulenc's Gloria to boot. 8 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212)333-5333, $27 to $97. (Oestreich)

'NEW VISTAS' (Sunday) In an unusual event, Janice Mayer & Associates, an artists' representatives agency, will celebrate its 10th anniversary by throwing a benefit for Classical Action: Performing Artists Against AIDS. The event will be held in a jazz club, with beverages and hors d'oeuvres, and an informal program featuring a diverse roster of artists and composers. 1 p.m., Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola, Frederick P. Rose Hall, Broadway at 60th Street, (212)997-7717, $100 and $250. (Tommasini)

NEW YORK CHORAL SOCIETY (Tonight) It's like Giacomo in the Kentucky Derby: an amateur chorus overmatched in Beethoven's well-nigh unsingable ''Missa Solemnis.'' A risky proposition, it nevertheless affords the opportunity to shine. 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212)247-7800, $18 to $75. (Oestreich)

NEW YORK NEW MUSIC ENSEMBLE (Monday) Contemporary music often involves a measure of gamesmanship, or at least, a sometimes fluid negotiation between the composer and the performers (and sometimes the listeners). With game-playing as its theme, this first-rate group offers works by Hiroya Miura, Wayne Peterson, John Anthony Lennon, David Rakowski and Andrew Imbrie. 8 p.m., Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan, (212)501-3303, $15; $10 for students and 65+. (Kozinn)

PARTHENIA (Tonight) The sound of a viol consort, though quite rich on its own, is enhanced when it supports the voice. The superb Parthenia and the soprano Jolle Greenleaf will explore that combination in a program of Baroque Italian works and a contemporary piece by John Stone. 8 p.m., Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street, Morningside Heights, (212)358-5942, $25, $18 for students and 65+. (Kozinn)

PRISM SAXOPHONE QUARTET (Tonight) How many composers can you name that have written saxophone quartets? Right. That's why this versatile ensemble, now in its 20th season, has been so involved in creating and performing brand new music. Tonight it plays several premieres, including one by Lee Hyla. 8:30 p.m., Thalia at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street, (212)864-5400, $21, $18 for students and 65+. (Eichler)

RIVERSIDE CHORAL SOCIETY (Tomorrow) The 24-year-old chorus's spring concert includes works by Brahms, Mendelssohn, Pavel Chesnokov, Eric Whitacre and John David Earnest. 8:30 p.m., Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan, (212)501-3330, $30.(Midgette)

ST. LUKE'S CHAMBER ENSEMBLE (Monday) The second of two ''Masters of the Baroque'' concerts by this group focuses on brass instruments on the one hand and music of Josquin and Gabrieli on the other. 6:30 p.m., Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, (212)594-6100, free. (Midgette)

WORKS AND PROCESS (Monday) Musicians and singers including Lucy Shelton and Fred Sherry take a look at what Milton Babbitt, American music's ageless guru of the avant-garde, is up to these days. 8 p.m., Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue at 89th Street, (212)423- 3587, $20. (Holland)

Dance
