HEADLINE: Hoping the Good News Holds, El Paso Prepares for Major Growth at Fort Bliss

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

DATELINE: EL PASO, May 17 

 BODY:
''It's a great day to be a soldier,'' proclaims the big sign at El Paso International Airport. 
 It is a great day, too, for struggling El Paso, or it will be if the Army follows through with plans for a huge buildup at Fort Bliss, the neighboring Army post and air defense center, which is set for the greatest increase in the number of troops under Pentagon recommendations announced on May 13.
 ''It's so significant, it's hard to put into words, an economic impact of maybe $2.5 billion a year,'' said Richard E. Dayoub, president of the Greater El Paso Chamber of Commerce, who spent May 14 at a Soldier Appreciation Picnic dishing out so much barbecued brisket that he was nursing a cramp in his hand. 
 If the expansion plans survive a coming round of hearings by the Base Realignment and Closure Commission, Fort Bliss -- larger than Rhode Island and the only installation where every weapon in the Army arsenal can be fired -- would see its military strength, now about 18,000 soldiers and civilians, grow by more than 50 percent. Its net gain, over the next six years or so, would be 11,354 troops. 
 That would prove a welcome boost for El Paso, a sun-baked city of 563,000 that was known as the blue jeans capital of the world until the garment industry took flight in the 1990's.
 Until then, many agree, El Paso -- sprawled at the feet of the jagged Franklin Mountains across the Rio Grande from Juarez, Mexico, and closer to Los Angeles than to Beaumont in East Texas -- took its military neighbor largely for granted. City officials barely noticed when an earlier round of base changes moved the 4,600 soldiers of the Third Armored Cavalry Regiment to Fort Carson, Colo., from Fort Bliss in 1995. Only when restaurants and shops around the post started closing did the loss become evident. 
 ''I think we were a little naive in the process,'' said Mayor Joe Wardy, who was not in office then. 
 What a difference a decade makes.
 With the factories that once turned out two million pairs of jeans a week shuttered and with unemployment soaring, El Paso's military and political establishment joined forces three years ago to begin lobbying the Pentagon to keep and to expand Fort Bliss. Foremost in their minds, city officials say, was the $1.7 billion a year the post pumped into the local economy.
 Magnifying the regional effect is Fort Bliss's integration with two contiguous bases, White Sands Missile Range and Holloman Air Force Base, both in New Mexico. The three installations, with a combined footprint as big as Connecticut, account for about one-quarter of the Army's land in the United States and contribute more than $2.5 billion into regional economies. 
 ''Never has the El Paso region been so well organized to tell decision makers that this is a military user-friendly place, never,'' said Maj. Gen. James P. Maloney, retired, who was commander of Fort Bliss from 1982 to 1985 and is the West Texas representative on the Texas Military Preparedness Commission. The panel was named by Gov. Rick Perry to promote the state's vast military interests. The 18 major military installations in Texas are home to 190,000 service members, who represent nearly 11 percent of the nation's armed forces and 27 percent of all active-duty combat ground forces. 
 Fort Bliss's rosy prospects are in marked contrast to those of 33 other major installations around the country recommended for closings and hundreds more proposed for reductions. Texas would lose almost 8,000 military and civilian slots through three base closings in Corpus Christi, San Antonio and Texarkana, and even Fort Bliss would lose 4,564 soldiers from an air defense artillery unit transferred to Fort Sill, Okla. 
 But those losses would be offset by more than 16,000 arriving troops and civilians from the proposed realignment, including 3,800 troops of the First Cavalry Division due in from various places this summer. 
 Fort Bliss, named for a lieutenant colonel in the Mexican War, was established in 1848 with six rifle companies to chase Indians. It was a cavalry post until World War II, when it became an anti-aircraft training center and eventually grew into the military's leading air defense training center. It also includes a sergeant major training school, and is home to the German air force's own air defense school, established in the United States in part to offset the costs of keeping American troops in Germany. 
 It is also the proud home, the command says, of the Army's largest bowling complex (52 lanes); its largest banquet hall, the Centennial Club (60,000 square feet, with a 14,000-square-foot banquet area); and a PX the size of a Wal-Mart.
 Now, with the proposed addition of the armored troops from Europe, Fort Bliss is also poised to grow as a combat deployment center along the lines of Fort Hood, in Killeen, Tex., a major staging post for Army operations in Iraq. 
 With more than a million acres, Fort Bliss is ''a natural for significant expansion,'' General Maloney said, as home bases have yet to be designated for the rest of the 70,000 troops coming home. 
 Such speculation thrills local boosters like Mr. Dayoub, the chamber of commerce president, who said the city was rushing ahead with plans to accommodate the newcomers. ''We've been inundated with calls and meetings about the school districts and housing,'' he said. Fort Bliss and El Paso's public water utility are about to begin construction on what they say is the world's largest inland desalinization plant, capable of filtering 27.5 million gallons of brackish aquifer water a day. 
 ''In the medium-term, we don't see anything else emerging as a growth industry,'' said Dennis L. Soden, executive director of the Institute for Policy and Economic Development at the University of Texas at El Paso.
 Over the last 10 years, Dr. Soden said, Fort Bliss has generated about 11 percent of the local economic activity. ''Every ninth person in line at the store is there because of Fort Bliss,'' he said. 
 Military dollars are especially welcome in El Paso, where the unemployment rate in March stood at 7.7 percent, more than two percentage points above the Texas and national figures. Data from the Commerce Department show the city with a per capita income of $20,129 in 2002, ranking it 312th of 318 nationwide statistical metropolitan areas, said Tom Fullerton, an economics professor at UTEP. A greater military payroll, he said, would raise the area's average earnings, because the average annual pay for civilian jobs in El Paso, $33,970, is far below the military figure, $55,634. 
 So it seems hardly surprising that El Paso just started a monthlong Freedom Fiesta to honor the troops with parties, sports outings and discount-shopping expeditions, under the slogan ''We don't need a war to thank a soldier.''
 The opening picnic at a park on the post drew 8,000 service personnel and family members, and was followed by a golf tournament on the grounds of the posh Coronado Country Club on Monday. 
 ''Can't beat this,'' said Capt. Andy Haskell, assigned to a Patriot missile brigade, as he did battle with the 14th hole.

HEADLINE: Two Belgians Win Top Prize At Cannes for Second Time

BYLINE: By MANOHLA DARGIS and A.O. SCOTT

DATELINE: CANNES, France, May 21 

 BODY:
''The Child,'' a Belgian film directed by Jean-Pierre Dardenne and Luc Dardenne, won the Palme d'Or as best film at the 58th Cannes Film Festival on Saturday night.
 The film, which follows a young petty thief as he struggles with the moral dilemmas of fatherhood, was inspired by Dostoyevsky's ''Crime and Punishment'' and influenced by the classic French film ''Pickpocket,'' by Robert Bresson.
 This is the second time the Dardenne brothers have won the festival's top prize; ''Rosetta,'' their harsh look at work and unemployment in Belgium, took the award in 1999. 
 Paternity was a theme of more than one of this year's winning films, and of many that did not win. The jury, which included the Nobel Prize-winning writer Toni Morrison and the actors Javier Bardem and Salma Hayek, gave its Grand Prix, the festival's second-highest award, to Jim Jarmusch for ''Broken Flowers,'' a comically poignant portrait of a middle-aged Lothario (Bill Murray) searching for a son he did not know he had. 
 Mr. Jarmusch, in his acceptance speech, called the jury ''strange'' and acknowledged a number of other directors in the competition, including Gus Van Sant, Atom Egoyan and Hou Hsiao-hsien, whom Mr. Jarmusch called his teacher.
 The Jury Prize, a kind of honorable mention, was given to ''Shanghai Dreams,'' Wang Xiaoshuai's tale of proletarian unhappiness in provincial China in the early 1980's. 
 The prize for best male performance, in a year of strong contenders (including Mr. Murray, Viggo Mortensen in David Cronenberg's ''History of Violence,'' Kevin Bacon in Mr. Egoyan's ''Where the Truth Lies'' and Jeremie Renier in ''The Child''), went to Tommy Lee Jones for ''The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada,'' which he also directed.
 In addition, that film earned Guillermo Arriaga the screenwriting award. ''The Three Burials'' is about a modern Texas cowboy (Mr. Jones, speaking both Spanish and English) on a mission to bury and avenge his murdered friend, an undocumented immigrant from Mexico. 
 America was clearly on the minds of many filmmakers in the competition, including the Danish director Lars von Trier, who has never set foot on American soil, and the German director Wim Wenders, who has lived in the United States for many years.
 Neither Mr. von Trier's entry, ''Manderlay,'' his follow-up to ''Dogville,'' nor Mr. Wenders's ''Don't Come Knocking,'' which revisits some of the themes he explored in ''Paris, Texas,'' won any prizes, though both directors have won Palmes in the past. 
 The jury selected Hanna Laslo as the festival's best actress for her role in the Israeli director Amos Gitai's ''Free Zone.'' Ms. Laslo, who plays a brusque Israeli taxi driver in the film (which also stars Natalie Portman), shared her prize with her mother, a Holocaust survivor, and with the victims from ''both sides'' in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
 ''Free Zone'' was one of many films in the festival that engaged contemporary issues directly rather than through allegory. Similarly, Mr. Jones's film, in spite of poetic and symbolic flourishes, concerns itself with problems on the border of the United States and Mexico. And ''The Child,'' in spite of its literary pedigree, is grounded in the brutal conditions of poor and disenfranchised citizens of modern Europe. 
 Contemporary European social issues were as much a theme at Cannes this year as American policy and politics. The Director's Prize went to the Austrian director Michael Haneke (who now works mainly in France) for ''Hidden,'' which touches on France's long, painful involvement in Algeria.
 The film, which stars Juliette Binoche and Daniel Auteuil, was a critical favorite. It was acquired for North American distribution by Sony Pictures Classics.
 The Camera d'Or, for the best first feature, went to two films: ''The Forsaken Land,'' directed by Vimukthi Jayasundara, about a small group of people living in a desolate part of Sri Lanka; and Miranda July's ''Me, You and Everyone We Know,'' a quirky look at life in Los Angeles, where everyone seems to be lonely as well as odd.

HEADLINE: Solution Has Become Problem for Braves

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
THE Atlanta Braves, Dan Kolb has learned, are not the Milwaukee Brewers. The Braves may have once played in Milwaukee, but we're not in Milwaukee anymore, Toto.
 Kolb was a seemingly clever answer to one of the Braves' off-season problems.
 If the Braves had one consistent shortcoming in the first 10 years of their unparalleled 13-year first-place run, it was the lack of a reliable closer. Then they solved the problem by taking John Smoltz out of the starting rotation and making him their closer. He quickly became one of the best, dominating ninth innings of games and gaining 144 saves in three seasons. 
 Then the Braves developed another problem: a shortage of starting pitchers. Instead of signing or trading for two starters, they acquired one, Tim Hudson, and made another trade that enabled them to restore Smoltz to the rotation. They obtained Kolb, who had 60 saves for Milwaukee the past two seasons. 
 After a shaky start in his new job, though, Kolb is on hiatus. 
 ''Dan Kolb pitched effectively last year,'' said John Schuerholz, the Braves' general manager. ''He came to us with high expectations and has to get accustomed to pitching in this high-expectation environment. That has varying degrees of acclimation. Some guys do it faster than others. He's not the 11th pitcher or a utility infielder. He's a key guy. He's struggling. He's not doing well. No question about that.''
 As a closer for the Brewers, Kolb failed to preserve a victory 7 times in 67 opportunities. In 13 chances with the Braves, he has squandered the save three times, including twice in his last three chances, both times depriving Smoltz of a victory. When he gave up two ninth-inning runs last Tuesday night for a 3-2 San Diego victory, Manager Bobby Cox gave Kolb a timeout.
 ''Bobby is saying we'll mix it up for a bit,'' Schuerholz said. ''We'll put Dan in situations where he can throw his stuff and feel comfortable. Bobby will try to match up his pitchers with the lineup we're facing, with hope that Dan will right himself and get back in the role we got him for.''
 Without an effective closer, the Braves would have trouble finishing first for the 14th successive time. Could the Kolb development be the first crack in the Braves' solid front?
 ''It's the right move right now,'' Schuerholz said. ''It doesn't mean anything other than the fact that this isn't working. We can't allow it to continue. We have to make adjustments.''
 Throughout their streak, the Braves have brought in new players every winter, and Cox has adeptly fit them into the team. Some of those newcomers have said it's easy to fit in and play for the Braves because they are a winning team.
 ''I don't know how you quantify it, but it's clearly different,'' Schuerholz said when asked about the Braves' environment. ''We're fully conscious of that. It's one of the factors you weigh in the equation when you consider a person.''
 It was considered in Kolb's case.
 ''It's a factor we talked about,'' Schuerholz said. ''It was something we were cognizant of. Obviously, doing it in Milwaukee carries with it less expectation than doing it for Atlanta. I think that's part of it. He has to get comfortable with it. He has 10 saves, but it's the five or six games we let get away from us.''
 Schuerholz is not ready to give up on Kolb or the Braves' chances with him as their closer. ''This is a team that was structured with good intent, with a good plan,'' he said. ''I think it will still work.''

A Rivalry Is on the Horizon
 Had the Montreal Expos been moved to Washington earlier, they would most likely be playing in Baltimore this weekend instead of in Toronto. That's just one more problem created by the extended time it took Major League Baseball to make the D.C. decision.
 Katy Feeney, the senior vice president in charge of baseball's scheduling, said: ''By the time the Expos actually moved, the schedule was done, so we left the Nationals in Toronto for one last year. If we had tried to change it, it would have meant a lot of other changes, not a simple flip-flop with Philadelphia.''
 Even though they played in the 1983 World Series, Philadelphia and Baltimore never looked like rivals except for their geographic proximity. Feeney said she expected the Orioles and the Nationals to play at least one series next season.
 Peter Angelos, the Orioles' owner, single-handedly helped create a rivalry by trying to keep the Expos out of Washington, threatening to sue baseball, then holding relocation hostage until baseball agreed to the financial terms he wanted in a deal that protected his team's economic base.
 The only potential problem with an Orioles-Nationals series: If it's played in Washington, will Angelos insist that he is entitled to the revenue? On the other hand, before it gets to that point, if the teams were to play only one series, Angelos would probably demand it be played in Baltimore because he knows the games would sell out, the way the Orioles used to sell out all of their games before he destroyed their status as a contender.

Don't Look for a Free Pass
 Carlos Guillen, Mark Teixeira and Lyle Overbay probably don't know it, but they are linked in one of the most remarkable feats of the season. Garret Anderson and David Dellucci are linked in a similarly remarkable feat.
 Guillen and Teixeira were the only two batters Minnesota's Brad Radke had walked in 63 innings before he walked Overbay last night in going six innings and taking the loss in the Twins' 6-0 defeat to the Brewers. Anderson and Dellucci are the only two batters Radke's teammate Carlos Silva has walked in 52 innings. Making Silva's feat even more eye-opening, the walk to Anderson was intentional.
 Radke and Silva are the best at not walking batters on a pitching staff that doesn't walk many. The Twins have walked 57. The team with the next best control, Cleveland, has walked 102.
 Rick Anderson, the Twins' pitching coach, doesn't get the attention that some other pitching coaches do, but he certainly has his pitchers throwing strikes, the goal of all pitching coaches.
 ''Radke can throw any pitch over at any time,'' Manager Ron Gardenhire said. ''He commands more pitches in the strike zone -- fastball, curve, slider, change -- and he can throw them at any time. Silva is mainly a sinker-slider pitcher. He attacks the outer half of the plate and gives up some ground-ball base hits.'' 
 Johan Santana, the Twins' Cy Young award winner last season, is a wild man compared with Radke and Silva. He has walked seven in 611/3. innings.

Have Bat, Will Travel
 For the first time in seven seasons, Reggie Sanders is playing for a team for the second successive season. He is the St. Louis Cardinals' primary left fielder, and he can finally send out his laundry.
 Sanders, 37, is a prototypical player in the free-agent era, not the highly sought star who signs a lucrative multiyear contract, but the journeyman who temporarily fills a hole for a team, then moves on to the next team that has a hole.
 Sanders, who played for Cincinnati in his first seven seasons in the major leagues, made his first two moves in trades, the Reds sending him to San Diego in February 1999 and the Padres moving him to Atlanta 10 months later. Then came free agency and visits to Arizona, San Francisco and Pittsburgh. 
 In his fourth time as a free agent, Sanders signed a two-year, $6 million contract with the Cardinals. This is the second year of that contract, meaning he can be a free agent again in November.
 In virtually every stop on his journey, Sanders has made his presence felt. Four of his last five teams have reached the playoffs, and three of the last four have played in the World Series. He won a ring with the Diamondbacks in 2001, batting .304 against the Yankees.

Selig Surrenders
 Bud Selig likes to get credit for creating interleague play and the wild cards in the playoffs. Now he gets credit for another distinction. He is believed to be the first commissioner to invite Congress into Major League Baseball instead of telling it to mind its own business and let baseball run its business.
 Selig, speaking about steroids testing, told a Congressional hearing last week, ''I would not resist federal legislation if Congress continues to believe that a uniform standard for all sports is necessary.''
 This was Selig's official act of surrender to Congress. No mas, he cried, throwing up his hands and demonstrating that he didn't like the public beatings he had taken. In the two months between hearings, the commissioner found religion, and he wanted everyone to hear him declare: ''I believe. I believe.''
 Selig resembled the Paul Newman character in the movie ''Cool Hand Luke,'' who after a series of beatings for his escapes from a chain gang eagerly obeyed orders. ''Yes, boss. Yes, boss,'' he said repeatedly with a smile. Only Luke was faking it. Selig is sincere.
 In his born-again ecstasy, perhaps Selig would have even gone before the House Un-American Activities Committee in the early 1950's and revealed as many names as Joe McCarthy, his infamous home-state senator, wanted. 
 Representative Tom Davis, Republican of Virginia, and his colleagues treated Selig roughly at their March 17 hearing, and he has demonstrated obeisance ever since. He has yet another chance to enhance his position with Congress. Yet another House committee is conducting a ''legislative inquiry'' into steroid use in sports, and it will surely lead to another hearing. Selig can't wait.


CORRECTION-DATE: May 26, 2005

 CORRECTION:
A Spotlight Baseball column on Sunday about Congressional testimony by Bud Selig, the commissioner of Major League Baseball, referred incorrectly in some copies to the movie in which the character played by Paul Newman is beaten after repeated escape attempts -- a plot line to which the commissioner's experience was compared. The film is ''Cool Hand Luke,'' not ''Hud.''

HEADLINE: Stocks Rally as Oil Prices and Inflation Recede

BYLINE: By JEFF SOMMER

 BODY:
Despite a dip on Friday, stocks rallied last week and the three major market gauges rose as oil prices fell and government reports suggested inflation was dormant.
 The Labor Department reported that core consumer prices, which exclude food and energy, were unchanged in April. 
And both the Conference Board and the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia issued reports indicating that economic growth was slowing, fueling hopes that the Fed would be restrained in raising interest rates.
 Shares of Home Depot rose 9.2 percent and were among the best performers in the Dow Jones industrials. The company's first-quarter profit beat expectations and sales of big-ticket appliances soared. Lowe's, the main competitor of Home Depot, also reported a jump in earnings, and its shares gained 8.7 percent for the week. 
 For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 331.79 points, or 3.3 percent, to close at 10,471.91. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 35.23 points, or 3.1 percent, to close at 1,189.28. The Nasdaq composite index rose 69.64 points, or 3.5 percent, to close at 2,046.42. 
 The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury bond, at 4.12 percent, remained unchanged from the previous week. JEFF SOMMER

HEADLINE: Charter for the European Union Meets Resistance

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

DATELINE: AMSTERDAM, May 19 

 BODY:
For a quarter of a century, it has been pretty much assumed in the half-dozen founding countries of the now 25-member European Union that popular support for an ever bigger and more unified Europe would be virtually automatic. 
 Not anymore. At least not if large segments of public opinion in the founding states of France and the Netherlands matter. 
 In both countries, referendums are planned soon on whether to ratify the painstakingly written, 450-page draft of the new European constitution that, its sponsors say, is the indispensable blueprint for the next stage of growth and unification of what is called the European project.
 But ratification has run into a surprisingly vigorous grass-roots opposition in these countries, representing a revolt among sizable numbers of the project's supposed core constituency. 
 ''It surprised me,'' Bernard Bot, the Dutch foreign minister, said of the surge in opposition to the constitution, which he helped negotiate.
 ''I was out canvassing the other day, and I met a woman who said there was no point in trying to convince her, she was going to vote no. I asked her why, and she said, 'I just feel good saying no for once.'''
 ''There's a lot of irrational reaction that has to do with the general economic situation in the country, European enlargement and immigration,'' Mr. Bot continued in an interview in his office in The Hague. ''You can take any issue that has come up in the last few years, and it's a reason to vote no.''
 Or, as Daniel Cohn-Bendit, the former student radical who is now a German member of the European Parliament, put it, ''The feeling of the people is that we want to say no to what exists to prove that we exist.''
 The draft constitution itself is a four-part document that does many things, among them establishing power-sharing among European Union members and detailing, in some 50 articles, a list of basic rights. The draft also determines in painstaking detail what functions -- like issuing visas or establishing rules on immigration -- will go to the European Union headquarters in Brussels and what others -- like taxation, foreign policy and defense -- will remain with member states. 
 All 25 current members of the European Union must ratify the draft for it to take effect; nine countries already have, Austria, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Italy, Lithuania, Slovakia, Slovenia and Spain. All ratified it by parliamentary vote. Spain, however, had a nonbinding referendum, followed by parliamentary ratification. 
 But France and the Netherlands have chosen ratification by referendum. (In the Netherlands, results can be overturned by the Parliament.) The French vote is set for May 29 and the Dutch for June 1. No votes could doom the current draft and, with many states probably not willing to go through the long, politically fraught process of rewriting the text, the European Union would run under the existing rules indefinitely. The referendum campaigns have unleashed powerful emotions in France and the Netherlands that are often only loosely connected, if at all, to the actual constitutional text. The fears seem almost as varied as the people expressing them: from the worry among the Dutch that their liberal practices regarding private drug use and gay marriage will be eroded, to anxieties that uncontrolled immigration is destroying the Dutch quality of life, to an almost aesthetic distaste for the draft constitution's establishment of a European anthem, based on Beethoven's ''Ode to Joy,'' and a European national holiday.
 ''How can you create a constitution for a nonentity?'' said Leon de Winter, a Dutch filmmaker and political commentator who is a leading opponent of ratification. He was expressing a sentiment common in the Netherlands -- that a Europe stretching from Portugal to Ukraine and likely to include Muslim Turkey is a kind of illusion, a figment of the bureaucratic imagination with very little in the way of a unifying purpose or a unifying vision. 
 ''I don't want Europe to be a unified power,'' Mr. de Winter said. ''I don't want Europe to have a foreign minister, or to be a competitor for power with the United States.'' 
 To a great extent in France and the Netherlands, the possibility of a no vote is closely linked to the unpopularity of the governments in power -- that of President Jacques Chirac in France and an unwieldy three-party coalition in the Netherlands whose approval rating is a dismal 20 percent or so. 
 In France, in addition, the constitution has provoked a powerful fear that the European project is a sort of back door for what is called ''liberalism,'' or ''ultraliberalism,'' meaning liberalism in the European sense of Anglo-American style free-market economics, which, many people contend, would strip away social protections and raise already high levels of unemployment.
 ''The no camp has linked the constitution to the idea that Europe is unsocial and liberal,'' Mr. Cohn-Bendit said. ''So they think, if you smash the constitution, you smash liberalism, and this emotion runs very deep in the French population.''
 A few weeks ago, Mr. Chirac held a widely watched televised discussion about the constitution with a group of 18-to 30-year-olds, in which he seemed taken aback by the conviction, as one of the young people put it, that ''the text follows a liberal logic.'' Mr. Chirac did his best to convince his young fellow citizens that a no vote would usher in the very savage capitalism they feared, but the latest polls in France, published in Le Monde a week before the referendum, showed the no camp holding 53 percent of the vote, though the high percentage of undecideds made a firm prediction of the outcome impossible. 
 In the Netherlands, an old trading nation, there is little of the fear of ''ultraliberalism'' that predominates in the no camp in France, but more a sense that the rapid expansion of Europe well beyond its original core will contribute to what is widely perceived as a deterioration of the quality of life. The greatest fear seems to be that Dutch immigration policy will be controlled by unelected European Union bureaucrats in Brussels, rather than by local leaders who can be held to account. The prospect of Turkish membership in this sense is a big issue in the Netherlands, which was shocked deeply over the murder last year of the filmmaker Theo van Gogh by an Islamic fanatic. Now, public figures move around with teams of bodyguards. 
 ''The political elites told us that the multicultural thing would be an enrichment, but most people have seen the reality -- unemployment, ethnic ghettos, high criminality and the rise of radical Islam,'' Mr. de Winter said. ''So there's a basic feeling that we don't believe what our politicians tell us.'' 
 Meanwhile, in the past couple of weeks the pro-constitution camp has been jolted by revelations in the Dutch news media that a decade ago when the Netherlands switched to the euro, the common European currency, the Dutch guilder was undervalued by about 10 percent. This has produced a movement, led by a group's Internet campaign, to sue the government for damages. The group says it has received 6,000 pledges of about $65 each in its first few days of existence. 
 Anticonstitution campaigners, like Geert Wilders, a maverick populist member of Parliament and a leading anti-immigration campaigner, have toured the country to warn that the Dutch will lose control of their own borders. Mr. Wilders's campaign slogan is ''The Netherlands Must Stay,'' meaning that in an ever larger, ever more bureaucratic Europe, it will disappear.
 But proponents of the constitution like Mr. Bot make the opposite point, namely that a small country like the Netherlands is more vulnerable to uncontrolled immigration under the present system than under a future one.
 ''I have to remind people that if you say no, the E.U. doesn't cease to exist,'' he said. And under the present system, any country can admit any number of immigrants, as Spain recently did when it accepted some 700,000 previously illegal immigrants, and those immigrants can then move freely to any of the 25 member states. The new constitution would in essence, Mr. Bot contends, prevent Spain or any other country from determining the immigration risks of every other country. 
 ''The Netherlands is one of the founding fathers and a country with a very open economy and a very vulnerable one,'' Mr. Bot said. ''We cannot afford to say no. So I say to people: 'If you vote no in order to ventilate, you'll bring harm to yourself. You have to be seen as a team player in Europe and to understand the nature of the times in which you live.'''

HEADLINE: Unsettling In

BYLINE: By ERICA REX. 
Erica Rex received a National Magazine Award for fiction for ''The Novitiate,'' a short story published in The North American Review.

 BODY:
THEIR voices wake me from sleep. Although it is the middle of the night, light from the street has bathed my room in hazy half dawn, so at first I am disoriented, unclear of where I am, or who or what is causing the racket. For a moment, I think I'm still in North Fork, the town in the Sierra Nevada foothills in California I left three months before with both my 10-year marriage and my writing career in shambles. But at this moment I am unsure of where I am. I imagine a clear night under a full moon, and there's a raccoon in the yellow pine outside the window snarling at some foe. Maybe a bear has come down from the high country in search of food. It has been a dry year, and forage is scarce. Then the voices from outside the window jolt me awake.
 Male voices are cussing in high decibels. Profanities roll off their tongues as easily as nursery rhymes lilt from the mouths of preschoolers. Their conversation would have earned any child in North Fork a long trip to the woodshed. 
 Laughter. Hawking, spitting. Cigarette smoke wafts into my room. It is night, late spring, and the air in Brooklyn already feels hot and still, foreign and oppressive. I am actually sleeping naked, which ordinarily I never do. In the heat and humidity, I can't tolerate the feeling of a nightgown against my skin. Music from a bar across the street twaddles out plaintively like a lost child. I live on the ground floor of a prewar brick building in Bay Ridge. A group of teenage boys are leaning against the wall of my building beside my window, smoking and shooting the breeze. I turn on the light beside my bed, thinking that perhaps if they know I'm here, awake, and listening, they will go away. They don't budge.
 The clock beside my bed reads 2:30. There are more exclamations; someone begins recounting a tall tale about scoring. I'm not sure whether he means drugs, sex or basketball.
 I have lived in this apartment in Brooklyn only a few months. Since I didn't know better when I rented it from a long distance away, while I was still in California, I had no idea of how far Bay Ridge was from Manhattan, at least as far as public transportation was concerned. ''It's on the R train,'' the young woman I rented it from said cheerfully over the phone. ''The R is only three blocks from the apartment. Very convenient.''
 The R train, I quickly learned, is anything but convenient. The station is close enough, but the subway has a life of its own. The R train, which takes over an hour to actually deliver me to any Manhattan destination, if it comes at all, has become one of the major preoccupations of my new life. Subways in general, I discovered, are a kind of force of nature in the city. They are to New York what the weather was back home. People here discuss trains and the vicissitudes of trains more than any other topic, including politics and unemployment.
 Will the train be on time? How much time should I allow to get someplace I haven't been before? Will I be able to transfer to the express at Atlantic Avenue without having to wait another hour?
 Then there are the unexpected stoppages. And to make public transportation really challenging, there are night and weekend schedules involving route switches and track changes, the likes of which only a select few with special powers of divination can interpret.
 As a result, living in Bay Ridge does me about as much good in terms of engaging myself with the cultural life of the city as living in North Fork, which is an entire continent away. At this moment, however, the train is not my problem. I get out of bed, put on my robe, and walk toward the window. I clear my throat a few times to signify my approach, then pull open the blind. In the woods, nights are silent except for the occasional owl's hoot, or coyotes barking and yipping to one another across the ridge. In the woods, a small amount of noise and light will generally drive away loitering wildlife. In Bay Ridge, this is not the case: New Yorkers are so accustomed to noise and light, I wonder sometimes how they would function without it.
 A group of young men, perhaps five or six, dressed in baggy pants slung so low over their hips I can see a pierced navel or two, are standing nearby. Some are leaning against the building, some against street lamps. Their heads are covered with what looks like knotted ends of black pantyhose. Their lips and noses are decorated with multiple piercings. They wear high-top tennis shoes and socks; T-shirts embossed with logos and emblems denoting mysterious alliances, although I can't begin to guess what they might be. One of the boys notices me, and their voices gradually quaver into silence. One spits into the gutter and looks the other way, down the street toward the water.
 ''UM,'' I say, ''boys, would you, um, mind moving across the street? You see, my bedroom is right here, and I'm trying to sleep.'' One of them starts to say something; another cuts him off. 
 ''We didn't realize you were there, ma'am,'' the second one says. He is a tall, dark, heavyset youth of about 16. His black stocking cap is knotted at the crown like a little nylon beanie. ''We'll be going. Sorry to disturb you.''
 Casually, the others begin to move as well. They pull themselves away from the wall slowly, as though they were made of taffy and the heat was gluing their backs to the brick. They move off down the street toward Shore Road, lumbering slowly, casually, like bears in the high country, confident in the knowledge that no matter what they do, or what incursions into their territory they might tolerate, they still own the place. They may cede ground now and then, but me, I'm just renting.

HEADLINE: Laura Bush Backs Women In Mideast

BYLINE: By HASSAN M. FATTAH

DATELINE: SOUTH SHUNA, Jordan, May 21 

 BODY:
Laura Bush called for increased attention to women's rights in the Middle East on Saturday, the second day of a good-will mission to the region. 
 The first lady, speaking to business and political leaders at the World Economic Forum in this town on the Dead Sea, highlighted education and women's rights as central to fostering democracy in the Middle East, a major theme of the Bush administration. 
 Women have enjoyed ''extraordinary progress'' in recent months, she said, especially in Kuwait, where they won the right to vote earlier this month, and Lebanon, where they protested the Syrian presence there alongside men. 
 ''Women who have not won these rights are watching,'' she said. ''They are calling on the conscience of their countrymen, making it clear that if the right to vote is to have any meaning, it cannot be limited only to men.'' 
 Mrs. Bush is on a five-day tour of the Middle East. 
 Her comments on Saturday coincided with the release of a comparative assessment of women's rights in the Middle East by the American-based group Freedom House, which describes itself as a nonprofit, nonpartisan organization working for the expansion of democracy. 
 The organization's assessment sought to explain the causes and consequences of sex-based discrimination in the region. The organization says its study, paid for by the Department of State's Middle East Partnership Initiative, is the most comprehensive look at women's rights in 17 Arab countries. The study ranks countries on the rights and freedoms they offer women. 
 Of the 17 countries studied, all but Saudi Arabia have constitutions mandating the equality of women, but basic criminal, family and labor laws are consistently skewed against women, researchers found. None of the countries has a law declaring domestic violence a crime, and there are no efforts to inform women of the laws that do exist to protect them, said Sameena Nazir, director of the survey and a senior research coordinator at Freedom House. 
 ''We took care to make this a useful tool for women,'' Ms. Nazir said. ''It's not just another study to put on the shelf.''

HEADLINE: For a Frail Old Tenement, A Fortifying Dose of Goop

BYLINE: By EVE M. KAHN

 BODY:
A year ago, owners of condominium apartments at 241 Eldridge Street heard dire news. Cavities were forming within the brick walls of their century-old tenement, so much so that the place was held up largely by inertia. 
 Scott Henson, an architect whose Manhattan firm is restoring the building, offered residents two options. They could spend $1.4 million dismantling and rebuilding the decrepit walls, while protecting their apartments temporarily with wallboard and tarpaulins, or they could try a less invasive and less costly stabilization technique that had never before been used in the United States. 
 After examining sheaves of test reports and letters from scientists and engineers, residents voted unanimously to go with the avant-garde solution, even though it called for pumping the walls full of gray goop.
 ''We investigated enough to put our faith in it,'' said Robin Schanzenbach, president of the condo board. ''We've felt we're totally on the cutting edge.''
 The milky chemical, whose official name is micro injection grout, is manufactured by a German company called Jahn International, and its formula is secret. From Feb. 9 to April 22, construction crews drilled 1,435 holes into the building and pumped in 1,280 gallons of the mixture. Final price tag: $106,000. 
 The grout filled crannies between bricks, where mortar had been crumbling into dust, and it set in half an hour. It also sometimes made a mess. A dozen times it spilled onto apartment window sills or floors, but, as David Bergman, an architect who has lived in the building since 1995, pointed out, ''It cleans up very easily, with paper towels and 409 or Fantastik.'' 
 The Jahn product, which has been commonplace in Europe for 30 years, has been imported into the United States since the 1980's for small repair jobs, said Dennis Rude, chief executive of the distributor, Cathedral Stone Products. But Mr. Henson is the first customer to apply it to an entire building. 
 ''It's a drastic solution,'' said Norman Weiss, a professor of historic preservation at Columbia University. ''It's also a very exciting project. The idea could be applied to hundreds, maybe thousands of buildings that have problems the owners don't know about yet, or problems that have been covered with superficial repairs -- that's like putting makeup on what turns out to be melanoma.''
 The Eldridge Street building, a neo-Renaissance style structure, was built in 1904, but although the masons apparently lavished care on the facade, which is trimmed in terra-cotta scrollwork, they skimped elsewhere. By the 1970's the structure was abandoned, condemned and used as a drug den. A gallery owner, Nicholas Logsdail, bought the blackened shell from the city, and a veterinarian, Mary Finger, moved in and rebuilt it as condominiums. Her own 1,000-square-foot loft is listed for sale at $859,000. 
 Next door, at 245 Eldridge Street, stands a rental building that is a twin of No. 241. Its rear and side walls are coated with gray weatherproof stucco, and show signs of cracking and sagging. Catherine Economakis, a managing agent for the building with Granite International Management, did not return calls seeking comment on the condition of the brickwork. Mr. Henson said: ''We don't want to scare anybody, but we assume conditions in those walls are the same as here.'' EVE M. KAHN

HEADLINE: Kaifeng's Warning for America.

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF. 
E-mail: nicholas@nytimes.com

DATELINE: KAIFENG, China 

 BODY:
As this millennium dawns, New York City is the most important city in the world, the unofficial capital of planet Earth. But before we New Yorkers become too full of ourselves, it might be worthwhile to glance at dilapidated Kaifeng in central China.
 Kaifeng, an ancient city along the mud-clogged Yellow River, was by far the most important place in the world in 1000. And if you've never heard of it, that's a useful warning for Americans -- as the Chinese headline above puts it, in a language of the future that many more Americans should start learning, ''glory is as ephemeral as smoke and clouds.'' 
 As the world's only superpower, America may look today as if global domination is an entitlement. But if you look back at the sweep of history, it's striking how fleeting supremacy is, particularly for individual cities.
 My vote for most important city in the world in the period leading up to 2000 B.C. would be Ur, Iraq. In 1500 B.C., perhaps Thebes, Egypt. There was no dominant player in 1000 B.C., though one could make a case for Sidon, Lebanon. In 500 B.C., it would be Persepolis, Persia; in the year 1, Rome; around A.D. 500, maybe Changan, China; in 1000, Kaifeng, China; in 1500, probably Florence, Italy; in 2000, New York City; and in 2500, probably none of the above.
 Today Kaifeng is grimy and poor, not even the provincial capital and so minor it lacks even an airport. Its sad state only underscores how fortunes change. In the 11th century, when it was the capital of Song Dynasty China, its population was more than one million. In contrast, London's population then was about 15,000.
 An ancient 17-foot painted scroll, now in the Palace Museum in Beijing, shows the bustle and prosperity of ancient Kaifeng. Hundreds of pedestrians jostle each other on the streets, camels carry merchandise in from the Silk Road, and teahouses and restaurants do a thriving business.
 Kaifeng's stature attracted people from all over the world, including hundreds of Jews. Even today, there are some people in Kaifeng who look like other Chinese but who consider themselves Jewish and do not eat pork.
 As I roamed the Kaifeng area, asking local people why such an international center had sunk so low, I encountered plenty of envy of New York. One man said he was arranging to be smuggled into the U.S. illegally, by paying a gang $25,000, but many local people insisted that China is on course to bounce back and recover its historic role as world leader.
 ''China is booming now,'' said Wang Ruina, a young peasant woman on the outskirts of town. ''Give us a few decades and we'll catch up with the U.S., even pass it.''
 She's right. The U.S. has had the biggest economy in the world for more than a century, but most projections show that China will surpass us in about 15 years, as measured by purchasing power parity. 
 So what can New York learn from a city like Kaifeng?
 One lesson is the importance of sustaining a technological edge and sound economic policies. Ancient China flourished partly because of pro-growth, pro-trade policies and technological innovations like curved iron plows, printing and paper money. But then China came to scorn trade and commerce, and per capita income stagnated for 600 years.
 A second lesson is the danger of hubris, for China concluded it had nothing to learn from the rest of the world -- and that was the beginning of the end.
 I worry about the U.S. in both regards. Our economic management is so lax that we can't confront farm subsidies or long-term budget deficits. Our technology is strong, but American public schools are second-rate in math and science. And Americans' lack of interest in the world contrasts with the restlessness, drive and determination that are again pushing China to the forefront. 
 Beside the Yellow River I met a 70-year-old peasant named Hao Wang, who had never gone to a day of school. He couldn't even write his name -- and yet his progeny were different.
 ''Two of my grandsons are now in university,'' he boasted, and then he started talking about the computer in his home. 
 Thinking of Kaifeng should stimulate us to struggle to improve our high-tech edge, educational strengths and pro-growth policies. For if we rest on our laurels, even a city as great as New York may end up as Kaifeng-on-the-Hudson.

HEADLINE: Off Base

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE KORB. 
Lawrence Korb, a former assistant secretary of defense, is a senior fellow at the Center for American Progress and a senior adviser to the Center for Defense Information.

 BODY:
THE residents of eastern Long Island and their elected representatives are understandably pleased that Francis S. Gabreski Airport, home to New York's Air National Guard's 106th Rescue Wing, was not on the list of bases that the Pentagon would like to close. After all, the base in Westhampton Beach employs a little more than 1,200 people and contributes about $100 million to the Long Island economy. 
 The decision to save Gabreski -- which was the subject of a $3 million lobbying effort led by Gov. George E. Pataki -- may be good for Suffolk County's economy in the short run. But the Pentagon's decision -- and I say this as someone who grew up in the region -- is not in the best interests of the country or the state, or even Long Island. Here's why. 
 The Base Realignment and Closure Commission was instituted two decades ago because the Pentagon was wasting about $20 billion annually maintaining more than 200 major bases that were no longer relevant to the military. From 1988 to 1995, the Pentagon was able to close 97 major bases and restructure 55 others for an annual savings of $7.3 billion. 
 But going into this latest round of base closings, the Pentagon still had at least 100 major bases that it no longer needed, but that were costing it around $10 billion a year. 
 The list prepared this month calls for closing only 33 major bases and cutting back another 29. The Pentagon claims this will eventually result in annual savings of $5.5 billion, and $48.8 billion over 20 years. But although many analysts think that this estimate is exaggerated, even if it is correct there are still at least 60 bases that are no longer needed and cost the taxpayer about $5 billion a year. Gabreski alone costs at least $50 million a year. 
 In deciding which bases to keep open, the Pentagon was supposed to give priority to bases that house more than one unit. Gabreski is home to a single unit, the 106th Rescue Wing, an elite search-and-rescue team that was depicted in ''The Perfect Storm.'' The Pentagon, meanwhile, is recommending the closing of the Niagara Falls Air Reserve Station, one of the other four bases in New York that house Air National Guard units, which is home to two units, the 914th Air Lift Wing and the 107th Air Refueling Wing. 
 Moreover, the Pentagon will need to spend a lot just to bring Gabreski up to minimum standards. For example, Gabreski has only 28 percent of the space it's supposed to have for its parachute rescue operations. Paradoxically, Congress allotted Niagara more than $14 million last year for upgrades. 
 Finally, had Gabreski been closed, its operations could easily have been moved to the Stewart Air Base in Newburgh, N.Y., thus keeping jobs from going out of state. The operations in Niagara, however, will be dispersed to places like Arkansas, Maine and Virginia. 
 While military value rather than economic impact is supposed to be the main criterion, the decision to close a base is supposed to take economic impact into account. While Gabreski generates about $100 million for Long Island's economy, Niagara generates more than $150 million. 
 Moreover, Suffolk County is better positioned than Niagara to absorb the cutbacks. The unemployment rate in Niagara is one-third higher than Suffolk and the poverty rate is almost twice as high. The median household income and average cost of housing in Niagara, on the other hand, are only about half those of Suffolk. 
 While keeping Gabreski open will no doubt have short-term benefits for the Long Island economy, in the long run, it would be better for its economy if that land were in the hands of the private sector. For example, Lowry Air Force Base in Denver, which was closed in 1994, has generated about $4 billion in economic activity, including $1.1 billion from housing and commercial property construction. 
 Similarly, in Charleston, S.C., the 1,400-acre shipyard along the Copper River that closed in 1993 has turned into a beehive of commercial and residential activities. Unlike Niagara, Westhampton Beach could easily emulate Denver and Charleston. 
 The list submitted by the Pentagon is only the first step in the base closing and realignment process. The nonpartisan commission will analyze the list and add or subtract as appropriate. In the previous four rounds, the commission has accepted 85 percent of the Pentagon's recommendations, but has added as well as subtracted bases from the list. It should take a close look at Niagara and Gabreski.

HEADLINE: The Great Democrat

BYLINE: By Scott Malcomson. 
Scott Malcomson, an editor at The Times Magazine, is the author of ''One Drop of Blood: The American Misadventure of Race.''

 BODY:

WHAT LINCOLN BELIEVED
The Values and Convictions of
America's Greatest President.
By Michael Lind.
358 pp. Doubleday.
$27.95.
 ''IN 1863,'' Michael Lind begins, ''the democratic republic as a form of government was rare -- and in danger of extinction.'' He then looks around the world at the governmental forms prevalent in that year. This seems an odd way to start a study of Abraham Lincoln, but such indirection is Lind's way of saying: if you want to read my book, you're going to have to do it my way. Happily, Lind is not just demanding; he is intellectually bold and an enthusiastic researcher. In large doses, ''What Lincoln Believed'' can get claustrophobic. But taken a little at a time and in a generous spirit, it will almost certainly change the way you think about America and one of its greatest presidents.
 Among the world's ruling classes, Lind shows, opinion was running against democracy in 1863. Republics had been coming and going since the French Revolution, but mostly they had been going, and it looked possible that the form might soon be gone. For Lincoln, ''government of the people, by the people, for the people,'' as he put it in his speech at Gettysburg, was the essential promise of the American Revolution and of the United States. If the Union could be pulled through this civil war, democracy might endure. If the Union fell, democracy might fall with it.
 This zeal to secure democratic government as a covenant for future generations, against the political tide of the times, is what Lind finds most worth celebrating in Lincoln. He calls him the Great Democrat. This picture is set against three previously prevalent images: the Great Commoner, the Savior of the Union and the Great Emancipator. 
 The first of these was part of Lincoln's own electoral mythology: the rail-splitter, studying by firelight, pressing ever forward with Midwestern grit. The Savior of the Union was, of course, a wartime image, but one grandly reasserted later in the 19th century as part of the effort to reconcile white Americans north and south. Lincoln the Great Emancipator, having been born in the last days of the war, went into a long hibernation as white Southern tribalism achieved its partial victory in the decades of racial segregation. This Lincoln re-emerged with the civil rights movement.
 Each of these stereotypes provides something like an anvil on which Lind hammers out his own ideas. Most of the pounding is at the expense of the Great Commoner and the Great Emancipator. Lincoln was a ''Henry Clay Whig,'' Lind explains: ''Henry Clay's plan for the American nation-state combined an industrial economy created by Hamiltonian methods'' -- that is, using protectionist tariffs and government spending to promote manufacturing and shrink the economic role of raw-material producers, mainly farmers -- ''with a white-only society created by Jeffersonian racial policies. His disciple Abraham Lincoln adopted Clay's entire nation-building program as his own.'' This was a democracy of aspiration, not mundane contentment; part of what made the commoner deserving of social honor was his desire to be uncommon. 
 Such a democracy had to grow, as its work was never done -- and this thrilling, nerve-racking growth came with the glow of destiny. ''But for the difference in habit of observation,'' Lincoln once wondered aloud, ''why did Yankees, almost instantly, discover gold in California, which had been trodden upon, and overlooked, by Indians and Mexican greasers, for centuries?'' As his language suggests, Lincoln saw American destiny as white. 
 For most readers today, Lincoln's protectionism and his promotion of cities will probably be more surprising than his casual (not theoretical) racism, or his belief that whites and blacks should be forever kept apart. After all, Lind is building on the ample work of W. E. B. Du Bois, Eugene H. Berwanger and Lerone Bennett Jr. -- and many others, although Lind's footnotes could have been more thorough than they are. By now it is, or should be, reasonably common knowledge that Lincoln, like Clay and a number of other leading antebellum American statesmen, believed sincerely in the mad project of resettling blacks, and in particular freemen, in warmer, more distant climes to create a white America.
 As Lind notes, the Free Soil movement so crucial to Lincoln's achieving the presidency was closely related to the colonization movement that preceded it. Both were concerned with sparing white workers from having to compete with black ones, initially in the newer states of the Midwest and then as far as California. A decisive portion of the population that settled these places came from the white lower classes of the South, people whose route upward was blocked by slave-owning Bourbons and whose route downward looked very like a descent, by degrees, into blackness. 
 Such were the Lincoln forebears who moved into Illinois. In 1856, according to one source cited by Lind, about half the number of people who had left the South had settled in Illinois and Indiana. As Lincoln said in the 1850's, ''Is it not rather our duty to make labor more respectable by preventing all black competition, especially in the territories?'' He went on to warn that if slavery were allowed to spread, ''Negro equality will be abundant, as every white laborer will have occasion to regret when he is elbowed from his plow or his anvil by slave niggers.''
 What might have been seen as separate questions -- the extension of black slavery and the existence of black people in America -- were rendered as one, because free black laborers, not just black slaves, were also expected to ''degrade'' white labor. Lind amply demonstrates Lincoln's acceptance of this view, though he fails to ask the obvious question: Was wage competition from blacks a reality, or likely to become one? 
 This failure seems odd, especially since the periodic fanning of white lower-class fears of degradation would be a feature of postbellum political life. Besides, a sizable prewar Southern literature argued that racial slavery for blacks was the only alternative to eventual wage slavery, under industrialization, for a great many whites. The tormented relationship of racial and economic bondage both predated the war and continued well beyond it.
 Lind argues that while Lincoln did preserve the Union, his deep wish to advance democracy went unrealized. ''The amount of the earth's territory controlled by Western empires,'' he writes, ''expanded from 35 percent in 1800 to 67 percent in 1878 and then to 85 percent in 1914.'' Lincoln's hopes of defending the best of the 18th century against the worst of the 19th were borne out only ''in the middle of the 20th century in a way he could not have expected. The principles of the post-1945 world order enshrined in the U.N. Charter, the U.N. organization and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights are those of the 18th-century American and French tradition of liberal republicanism.''
 By looking at Lincoln from many angles, Lind makes an already somewhat mysterious president still more puzzling and more interesting. But the Great Democrat image that closes his book doesn't really bring it all together. Lind evidently hoped to do an end run around Lincoln's detractors by erecting a previously unnoticed new Lincoln, one ruled by a passion for republicanism. This puts the emphasis on Lincoln's character rather than on what he did with his life. It's an approach that may serve our need for heroes. But Lincoln's legacy to us is in what he did, not who he was, a distinction Lincoln himself seemed to appreciate -- which was and is part of his continuing fascination.

HEADLINE: Flight to Quality Cuts Yields

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
WHILE there are several explanations for the surprising drop in Treasury yields in the last two weeks, the one cited most often has been what fixed-income traders call a flight to quality.
 That happens when investors want protection from some negative event that has occurred or one that may be around the corner. Concerns about some unexpected, significant losses in the hedge fund world have been bubbling up since Standard & Poor's cut the credit rating of General Motors and Ford Motor to junk bond, or high-yield, status on May 5. 
 The ''quality'' in the Treasury market is centered in Treasury bills and the two-year note. That is because shorter-term Treasury securities have smaller losses when interest rates rise. 
 The yield on the Treasury's six-month bill was 3.17 percent on Friday, down from 3.19 percent on Friday, May 6. The yield is also just above the 3.16 on May 2, the day before Federal Reserve policy makers announced their most recent quarter-point increase in their short-term interest rate benchmark, the fed funds rate, which they raised to 3 percent.
 Another way to look at this is using the spread, or difference, between the fed funds rate and, in this example, the two-year note. On May 2, the spread was 88 basis points. A basis point is one hundredth of a percentage point.
 Now that spread has narrowed to 66 basis points, which means that the two-year note has held its own, although the fed funds rate has risen 25 basis points.
 This rush to safety has also benefited the Treasury's 10-year note, whose yield was down to 4.12 percent on Friday, from 4.26 percent on May 6. But there is much less safety in holding these securities because the loss in principal from a sudden reversal in interest rates would be much larger.
 ''This is not a risk-averse trade; it is risk-seeking trade,'' said Louis Crandall, chief economist at Wrightson ICAP.
 So why is money flowing into the 10-year note? Mr. Crandall said it was because the fall in shorter-term rates would trigger a ''sympathetic'' drop in the yield of the 10-year note. And traders care mostly about direction, rather than fundamentals.
 ''Traders know this is the way the 10-year note behaves,'' Mr. Crandall said. ''So short-term money goes into it.''

FED SPEAK -- On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve will release the minutes from the May 3 meeting of Fed policy makers. Investors, as usual, will troll for nuances in language and tone that could clarify how worried policy makers are about inflation and when they might drop their promise to raise rates at a measured pace.
 But it is not clear if anything at all will be said about the surprising mistake Fed officials made in the statement they released after that May 3 meeting -- leaving out a sentence that said ''longer-term inflation expectations remain well contained.''
 The amending of the statement, which came about an hour and 40 minutes after the original 2:15 p.m. release, could turn up in an addendum to the minutes if there was an official communication among policy makers about the mistake. But some Fed watchers think it is more likely that the affair will not be mentioned.
 The absence of the sentence had investors thinking that the central bank was suddenly more worried about price pressures, sending interest rates higher. The correction revised that thinking.
 When the original statement was released, the price of the Treasury's 10-year note fell immediately but modestly. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 4.21 percent from 4.19 percent. 
 After the announcement of the correction, the yield fell quickly to 4.15 percent and the price jumped. That sudden swing, though not large, cost big-time traders real money.

DATA WATCH -- The report on orders for durable goods, which is due Wednesday, is expected to show a rise of 1.3 percent in April, after a drop of 2.3 percent in March, according to Bloomberg News. New home sales are forecast to have fallen 6.9 percent to an annual rate of 1.33 million.
 But economists expect that the better-than-expected trade data for March, which reflected stronger exports and weaker imports, will lead to an upward revision in overall economic growth in the first quarter. The new forecast is for 3.6 percent growth at an annual rate, up from the 3.1 percent reported when the first reading was issued in April.

HEADLINE: Coming Soon: A Theater Near You 

BYLINE: By STEPHEN WELLS

 BODY:
THE arts are often a study in paradox.
 It was only two years ago that arts institutions in New Jersey were in crisis, with state financing radically stripped by Gov. James E. McGreevey, only to be largely restored after public outcry. 
 At the same time this drama was playing itself out, various sources -- some of them public -- were committing tens of millions of dollars to build and renovate performing arts sites around the state.
 As a result, a steady stream of theaters and arts centers are opening, or are still being built at a rate that becomes difficult to count on two hands. Gleaming new structures and detailed blueprints illustrate the trend. 
 They include the $16 million, 350-seat Two River Theater in Red Bank, which opened this month, the $11.5 million, 431-seat Concert Hall at Drew University in Madison, which opened in February, and the $15 million South Orange Performing Arts Center, expected to open by next summer. 
 Several factors have prompted the renovation and creation of new spaces, even as the state has weathered an economic downturn and even though statistics indicate that over the last three years, theater attendance has dipped 12 percent. 
 Many of these projects have been fueled by donors, even as individual and corporate contributions for annual operating expenses at many institutions have remained level or in a few cases declined. Ralph Fylstra, a partner in Fylstra Wright and Company, an accounting firm based in Hawthorne whose clients include several professional theaters across the state, said he believed that there is one simple reason people often prefer to donate to a physical structure than to an organization's general expenses.
 ''It's tangible,'' he said. ''People like to see their money.''
 For Robert Rechnitz, it goes deeper than that. Mr. Rechnitz, who was a professor of American literature at Monmouth College in West Long Branch for 35 years, amassed considerable wealth through an investment he made early in his career, he said. By the time he retired in 1996, he had the means to freely pursue his love of the arts. 
 He founded the Two River Theater Company in the mid-1990's and became its executive producer, hiring a staff that transformed it into one of the state's more respected nonprofit theater companies. All that was missing was a theater they could call their own. Mr. Rechnitz recalls that as he and his wife, Joan, considered building one, he thought: ''Hey, man, you're running out of time. Take the shot or forget about it.'' 
 He decided to take the shot, financing much of the $16 million project himself. Very little expense was spared, or detail overlooked. 
 For example, the mechanical units for the theater's heating and air-conditioning systems are housed in a separate structure, connected to the theater building by pipes with rubber gaskets to prevent any undesirable noise from filtering in, said the principal architect, Stewart Jones, a Maplewood resident who is currently a partner in Meyer/Gifford/Jones, based in Manhattan.
 Similar highly sophisticated considerations have gone into the design of the Concert Hall at Drew University, which had sizable donations as well. 
 Thomas H. Kean, the former New Jersey governor who has been the school's president for 15 years, a post he will be relinquishing this summer, is generally acknowledged to be the driving force behind the complex that houses the concert hall, the 83,000-square-foot Dorothy Young Center for the Arts. The first two-thirds of the center, which includes theater arts and fine arts, opened in early 2003, but more financing was needed for the music wing. Mr. Kean secured a $5 million grant for the concert hall from the state's Economic Development Authority. Contributions to cover the rest of the cost then began falling into place.
 Though the concert hall is on the campus of a private university, the state's contribution ensures that it will be home to many non-student events and will serve as a showplace for professional artists. The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra has already played there, and according to its general manager, Susan Stucker, found the space ideal.
 Two other construction projects that benefited from individual aid were the Berlind Theater, which opened at the McCarter Theater Center in 2003, and the Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University, which opened in October. Roger Berlind, a Princeton graduate and Broadway producer, shared the $14.1 million cost for the 360-seat theater equally with the university and McCarter itself, which raised its share from 1,560 individual contributors. The $27 million construction cost of the 499-seat Kasser Theater was covered by a combination of university bonds and private donations.
 Many of the current rebuilding and construction projects have gained favor -- and financial backing -- because they are expected to provide an economic boost to their towns. Karen Francini, chief executive officer of the New Jersey Economic Development Authority, described arts construction as ''critical to helping revitalize our downtowns.'' She added that the arts are a key factor in attracting private investment. 
 The $3.2 million renovation of the Brook Arts Center, scheduled for completion by the end of the year, is seen as one of the catalysts for revitalization. The center first opened in 1927 as a vaudeville house, and was operating as a single-screen movie theater when Hurricane Floyd ravaged it, and much of downtown Bound Brook, in September 1999.
 Local officials drew up plans for a $3.2 million renovation of the Brook after a Federal Emergency Management Agency report on the disaster mentioned that an ''arts incubator'' would benefit the area. The United States Economic Development Administration committed 80 percent of the cost, and the remainder came from local and state funds. 
 Downtown South Orange's redevelopment is what spurred a federal contribution to the South Orange Performing Arts Center, which has been in the planning stages since 1995. The federal government is contributing an annual $250,000 Community Development Block Grant, which the village president, William Calabrese, says is enough to meet the principal and interest payments on the bond taken out to cover the cost of construction.
 The South Orange center not only will have a 415-seat space for live performances, but it will also have five movie theaters and a large ballroom. Mr. Calabrese said the goal was for the movie theaters and ballroom to produce enough income for the operation to be self-sustaining after it opens next summer.
 The State Theater in New Brunswick drew on a entirely different form of public financing for its interior restoration, completed last fall; the state's historical preservation fund paid the entire $3 million needed to return the structure to its original vaudeville-house glory. Even where a downtown revitalization is not needed, a thriving arts entity significantly benefits local and regional businesses. A 2003 economic impact study conducted by the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey indicates that the theater generated $2.7 million a year for the economy in and around Madison. 
 In addition to the potential benefits that a new structure will have for the community, many organizers of such projects hope that it will attract more patrons, and thus more than offset any increased operational expenses. If history is any indicator, there is substance to this line of reasoning. When the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey in Madison opened its fully renovated F.M. Kirby Shakespeare Theater in 1998, the number of subscribers doubled, its gross box office receipts rose by more than 50 percent and its total attendance grew by more than 40 percent. 
 Despite all the benefits a new facility can generate, the supply of capital is not endless, and it is not unusual for high-profile projects to still be scrambling to raise the final piece of the capital cost during the advanced stages of construction or even after their completion. 
 At Drew, one of the key figures involved in pursuing sources for the final $1.5 million still needed is Ron Ross, the university's vice president for development. Garyth Nair, a music professor at Drew and conductor of its orchestra and chorale, recalled a conversation with Mr. Ross a while back in which Mr. Ross suggested that the university would name the concert hall for the donor who contributes the final $1.5 million. 
 ''As long as it isn't Chuck E. Cheese,'' Mr. Nair responded.
 ''Look, if Chuck E. Cheese wants to give us one and a half million dollars,'' Mr. Ross shot back, ''we'll call it the Charles Fromage.''
