HEADLINE: U.S. SET TO TEST MISSILE DEFENSES ABOARD AIRLINES

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON

 BODY:
In an airplane hangar north of Fort Worth, technicians are preparing to mount a fire-hydrant-shaped device onto the belly of an American Airlines Boeing 767. It is an effort that could soon turn into a more than $10 billion project to install a high-tech missile defense system on the nation's commercial planes. 
 The Boeing 767 -- the same type of plane that terrorists flew into the World Trade Center -- is one of three planes that, by the end of this year, will be used to test the infrared laser-based systems designed to find and disable shoulder-fired missiles. The missiles have long been popular among terrorists and rebel groups in war zones around the world; the concern now is that they could become a domestic threat. 
 The tests are being financed by the Department of Homeland Security, which has been directed by Congress to move rapidly to take technology designed for military aircraft and adapt it so it can protect the nation's 6,800 commercial jets. It has so far invested $120 million in the testing effort, which is expected to last through next year. 
 Yet even before the tests begin, some members of Congress, and several prominent aviation and terrorism experts, are questioning whether the rush to deploy this expensive new antiterrorism system makes sense.
 Homeland Security officials have repeatedly cautioned that no credible evidence exists of a planned missile attack in the United States. But there is near unanimity among national security experts and lawmakers that because of the relatively low price and small size of the missiles, as well as the large number available on the black market, they represent a legitimate domestic threat. 
 The concern is not just for the lives that would be lost in the shoot-down of a single plane, proponents say. It is for the enormous economic consequences that would result if the public were to lose confidence in flying. 
 ''We are long overdue for a passenger aircraft to be taken down by a shoulder-launched missile,'' said Representative John L. Mica, Republican of Florida, who is pushing for the systems to be installed. ''We have been extremely, extremely lucky.''
 But a significant contingent of domestic security experts say the administration's focus on these missiles may be misdirected. They cite the broad range of ways that terrorists might strike next and point to studies showing that shoulder-fired missiles -- the most popular of which are American-made Stingers and Soviet-made SA-7's -- present less of a threat at airports than do truck bombs or luggage bombs.
 ''People have probably assumed that these kinds of weapons would work with much greater certainty,'' said K. Jack Riley, the director of the public safety and justice program at the Rand Corporation, a nonprofit research organization that has studied threats from shoulder-mounted missiles. ''This is not as big a threat as people might think.''
 Northrop Grumman and BAE Systems are competing to build the devices, which rely on plane-mounted sensors that detect heat-seeking missiles and then automatically fire infrared lasers to jam or confuse the missiles' guidance systems. The defense would be used for about a 50-mile area around airports, while planes land or take off.
 The American Airlines Boeing 767 and two jets owned by Northwest Airlines and FedEx will be tested to determine whether they remain as airworthy with the new technology aboard and to figure out if, in simulated attacks, the defense system is reliable. For now, no passengers will be aboard.
 Shoulder-fired missiles were introduced by the Americans and the Soviets in the 1960's to protect ground forces. A recent Congressional study found that more than 350,000 existed in government arsenals worldwide. But they also are a favorite of rebel groups and terrorists. At about six feet long and 50 pounds, they are easy to transport, and older models can cost only a few hundred dollars.
 Calls for putting the defense systems on commercial planes took on new urgency in 2002. That year, two missiles were fired at a Boeing 757 in Kenya that had been chartered by an Israeli airline. Both missed. 
 And in November 2004, an Airbus A300 cargo plane flown by DHL was struck by a missile on takeoff from the Baghdad airport. The plane lost hydraulic power but was able to land.
 ''This is one of the greatest dangers we face in the air,'' said Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, who has helped lead the push in the Senate for the deployment of missile defense systems. 
 Northrop Grumman and BAE Systems have briefed members of Congress, urging them to invest in the systems, and Northrop has commissioned a poll in an effort to demonstrate public support for the program. One Northrop briefing featured photographs of men in long, loose robes taking a missile launcher out of a car and firing a round into the air. 
 As the tests proceed, Homeland Security officials are looking for ways to lower the price tag. It has been estimated that it could cost $10 billion to install the systems on all commercial jets and as much as $40 billion over the next two decades, once maintenance and operational costs are added in. By comparison, the entire budget proposed for aviation security in the United States is $4.7 billion for the coming fiscal year.
 Homeland Security has asked BAE and Northrop Grumman to design systems that would cost no more than $1 million per plane, rather than the roughly $1.6 million some industry experts had expected. And the devices must work without need of repair for 3,000 hours, instead of the 300 hours required for military jets, according to specifications set by Homeland Security. 
 But even if the contractors can lower the costs, airline industry representatives and some terrorism experts say the price is hard to defend. 
 The Air Line Pilots Association, Boeing and the Air Transport Association of America are urging that more emphasis be placed on alternative defenses, like controlling areas around airports, limiting the international supply of missiles and making less expensive changes that would allow an airplane to fly even if its hydraulic system was lost. 
 ''The cost versus the benefit here does not play out,'' said Jim Proulx, a spokesman for Boeing. The presumption is that the government would pay to install the systems on existing planes, but the airlines would assume the ongoing maintenance and fuel costs, which could exceed $1 million a year per plane. 
 In a recent study by Rand, which examined security threats at Los Angeles International Airport, a shoulder-mounted missile was characterized as a ''lesser threat'' in terms of potential deaths than a truck bomb or a luggage bomb. In fact, the study suggested that the threat posed by a shoulder-fired missile was not much greater than that of a sniper who might fire a .50-caliber rifle at a plane from outside the airport.
 A separate study, financed by Homeland Security in 2004, said that the infrared systems would be useless or only marginally effective against several types of shoulder-mounted missiles.
 Part of the reason for the relatively low ranking of missiles among threats is that large passenger airliners are designed to fly after the loss of an engine, even if that engine explodes, industry experts said.
 Even before the current tests are complete, the Bush administration and Congress are moving to set aside $110 million for the next phase. Mr. Schumer and Mr. Mica also want to require that the devices be installed immediately on certain new commercial jets.
 And others, including Representative Steve Israel, Democrat of New York, and Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, want Congress to set aside $10 billion to install the systems on existing planes, perhaps first on the 1,000 aircraft that make up the Civil Reserve Air Fleet, which transports troops in times of war. The cost could be great, they said, but most likely smaller than the damage to the economy that would result from a single shoot-down. 
 ''We have been warned over and over again by the people who know,'' Ms. Boxer said, referring to classified briefings by the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. ''It is a race against time.''
 Yet Representative Christopher Cox, a California Republican who is chairman of the Homeland Security Committee, said the missile defense program was being driven too much by politics and lobbyists. 
 ''This is not the result of considered analysis of potential threats, terrorist capabilities or intentions,'' Mr. Cox said. ''It should be.''


CORRECTION-DATE: June 24, 2005

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on May 29 about plans by the Department of Homeland Security to test a defense system aboard airliners to locate and disable shoulder-fired missiles misstated the year that an Airbus A300 cargo plane was struck by a missile on takeoff from Baghdad. It was 2003, not 2004.

HEADLINE: Treading In the Shadow Of Bill Moyers

BYLINE: By TERRY GOLWAY

 BODY:
DAVID BRANCACCIO has inherited Bill Moyers's office, his job and his PBS program on Friday evening. It remains to be seen if he also will inherit Mr. Moyers's enemies.
 Mr. Brancaccio, a 45-year-old Maplewood resident, succeeded Mr. Moyers -- icon of the left and lightning rod of the right -- six months ago as the anchor of the public affairs program ''Now.'' 
 The transition was proceeding smoothly enough until several weeks ago, when it came to light that the chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting had ordered an analysis of the program's content after conservative critics charged that it was hostile to the White House. The chairman, Kenneth Y. Tomlinson, was appointed to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting by President Bush. 
 Suddenly, Mr. Brancaccio and his colleagues on ''Now'' were not just reporting news. They were in the news, an uncomfortable position for most professional journalists.
 For his part, Mr. Brancaccio -- who started his journalism career at age 15 as a reporter for a small radio station in Maine -- said he welcomes the scrutiny, if not the attention.
 ''I feel it is only fair that people with connections, apparently, to the White House would watch our show very carefully, because after all, we don't shrink from scrutinizing them,'' he said. ''Turnabout is fair play. The biggest fear we have is not that the White House may object to something we say. The biggest fear is getting something wrong, and there are many people who would love for us to get stuff wrong.''
 Mr. Brancaccio has been associated with the program since the fall of 2003, when it was known as ''Now with Bill Moyers.'' With Mr. Moyers's retirement in December, the show's name was changed to reflect its founder's departure, and Mr. Brancaccio was promoted from co-anchor to sole anchor. 
 But those were not the only changes. Because of financing issues, the show was cut from an hour to 30 minutes, and once a month the show features all interviews, which are less expensive to produce than heavily reported pieces from the field.
 "I'm agnostic on the change from an hour to half an hour, but one beautiful thing has happened as a result," Mr. Brancaccio said. "Even now, six months into the change, we are getting cascades of e-mails complaining about the shorter show. But that means that nobody is complaining about me -- we're not getting those letters that say, 'You're no Bill Moyers.'''
 When and if that charge is made, Mr. Brancaccio is fully prepared to concede its truth.
 ''Bill was a lightning rod because his life experience allowed him to put things together in a way that my life experience, which is shorter and different, doesn't,'' he said. ''I was not the deputy director of the Peace Corps. I did not work for Lyndon Johnson. Oh, and here's something else: I am not a Baptist minister. I'm the product of two parents from Brooklyn, one who was Jewish and grew up in Coney Island, and the other an Italian from Gravesend. And no matter how you add those up, you don't get Baptist.''
 But in acknowledging that he is no Bill Moyers, Mr. Brancaccio is quick to note that he is hardly seeking to distance himself from his former boss, mentor and friend. ''We still see each other,'' Mr. Brancaccio said, adding that Mr. Moyers still has an office down the hall on the sixth floor of Channel 13 headquarters on the far West Side of Manhattan.

How Moyers Chose Brancaccio
 Mr. Brancaccio came to the attention of Mr. Moyers and his wife and producer, Judith Moyers, through National Public Radio. Both were fans of Mr. Brancaccio's reports on the program ''Marketplace,'' which covers finance, business and globalization. ''We listened regularly in the kitchen and before we knew it, Brancaccio seemed to be there at the table with us,'' Mr. Moyers said. ''He made the news important without trying to sell us on his own importance. He was not a news announcer, but a storyteller.''
 Indeed, Mr. Brancaccio put his personal stamp on ''Marketplace'' in much the same way that Mr. Moyers did with ''Now.'' He broke in as the show's London correspondent in the early 1990's, covering economics and trade as the market-driven European Union came into existence. In 1994, Mr. Brancaccio moved to California and became the program's host and senior editor as its audience grew to more than 3 million, and its reach extended to nearly 300 stations. 
 ''Marketplace'' was not the usual business show, avoiding rote recapitulations of the market's ups and downs and sound bites from the practitioners of the two-handed science known as economics. 
 ''It was not all that different from what I do now,'' Mr. Brancaccio said. ''We covered issues from a human perspective, a populist version of business coverage. We were almost like anthropologists, on the outside looking into this alien culture that is business. We did it that way because while a third of our audience was made up of business professionals, two-thirds were not. So we had to make the show work for them.''
 Ken Kurson, a resident of Cedar Grove and business writer for Esquire magazine in the 1990's, said the appeal of ''Marketplace'' was that Mr. Brancaccio and his contributors ''seemed to love business.''
 ''They didn't cover business because it was a duty,'' said Mr. Kurson, who has become friendly with Mr. Brancaccio. ''They covered it because it was interesting and exciting, and seemed to have the correct sense that business can be a force for good.''
 The show certainly worked for Bill and Judith Moyers. ''When I started talking about finding a co-host to help me out on 'Now' and also be a potential successor when I retired,'' Mr. Moyers said, ''it was Judith who said, 'What about Brancaccio?' Ping!''
 ''We wanted to find a younger person for the show,'' he said. ''There weren't many younger people hosting shows in public broadcasting, and at the time the three network anchors were all veterans.''
 Mr. Brancaccio fit the bill.
 He had already broken into television, somewhat tentatively, with a public affairs program about California, a job he juggled along with his duties on ''Marketplace.'' Bill and Judith Moyers asked for tapes of the show. 
 ''Despite a set that swallowed the anchor and the guests, there was something there,'' Mr. Moyers said. ''And you have to keep this point in mind: One either has 'it' with the camera or one doesn't, and by 'it' I mean that chemistry which dissolves the distance between you and the viewers. I could see David had 'it.'''
 The Moyerses offered Mr. Brancaccio the post of co-anchor and heir apparent in the summer of 2003. But Mr. Brancaccio had more than just ''it.'' He also had a wife, Mary, a high school English teacher, and three school-age children. Accepting the job as Mr. Moyers's co-host would mean uprooting his family from California. What's more, Mr. Moyers told Mr. Brancaccio that ''Now'' was financed only through the end of 2004, and that the job could be very short-lived.
 ''People said, 'How could you think about leaving a show like Marketplace? You're identified with it, and it's a popular show hitting on all cylinders,''' Mr. Brancaccio said. ''That was absolutely true. But then I thought, 'Brancaccio, what would you pay to do a postdoctoral fellowship with Bill Moyers?' I'd say that I'd pay tens of thousands of dollars for that opportunity. But the offer on the table was that they would pay me.''

Needed to Live Near Trees
 But Mr. Brancaccio had to make a promise to his children: wherever they ended up in the New York area, they would live near trees. He and his wife found a house in the leafy town of Maplewood, which was recommended by a friend. Promise fulfilled.
 The adjustment to the East Coast in general -- and New Jersey in particular -- has not always been easy. Though he has Brooklyn roots, Mr. Brancaccio was reared in Maine, attended Wesleyan University in Connecticut (where he majored in history and African studies), and has lived in Ghana, Madagascar, London and Los Angeles.
 New Jersey is something new.
 ''It took me a while to come to grips with allowing other people to pump my gas,'' he said. ''And it took a while before I realized that all those restaurants that don't have liquor licenses are happy to have you bring your own wine.''
 He also had to adjust to the language change. ''I went into an Italian specialty store and asked if they had a particular kind of cheese, a white, firm ricotta,'' he said. ''And the answer was, 'Yeah, what do you think?' What I have come to realize is that this is Jersey-speak for, "Why, yes, I have the item that you are inquiring about and I am here to meet your customer service needs.'''
 Serving as anchor of a serious-minded, nationally broadcast television show has required adjustments of another sort. He noted that ''Now'' attracts staff rooted in the tradition of documentary filmmaking, while he is rooted in the faster pace of radio news. ''We have a great staff, but they don't always know what to make of this obstreperous radio guy,'' he said. ''There's also an earnestness that this show carries with it, and earnestness is not something that I do well. So we're learning from each other.''
 If earnestness is not his strong suit, explanation is, according to John Siceloff, the program's executive producer. 
 ''We live in an age of information overload, but David has the ability to cut through all of that and explain what's important,'' he said. ''And he does it with a twinkle in his eye.''
 Many reviewers say the show has not missed a beat since Mr. Brancaccio took over from Mr. Moyers -- including Mrs. Moyers. ''We're thrilled the way things have turned out,'' she said. But Mr. Kurson, Mr. Brancaccio's friend from Cedar Grove, thinks ''Now'' is ''still trying to find its legs'' in its new incarnation. 
 ''Television is a lot more of a collaborative effort than radio,'' he said, adding that so far he finds that the program lacks some of the spontaneity Mr. Brancaccio brought to ''Marketplace.'' Still, ''Now'' attracts about 1.5 million viewers, not to mention the ire of powerful people in Washington. A recent segment focused on the fate of terrorism suspects who have been jailed in Guantanamo Bay since the United States-led assault on the Taliban in Afghanistan. 
 ''This is not a Republican or a Democratic issue,'' Mr. Brancaccio said. ''Here's what is not in dispute -- these detainees have been there for three years, and are not being given access to what a normal American would view as due process. Are we O.K. with that? That's the question our journalism posed to viewers.''

Bristles at Conservative Critics
 Mr. Brancaccio said he would be disappointed if the show did not provoke sharp disagreement, but he bristled at the suggestion from conservative critics that ''Now'' has an ideological or partisan point of view. A recent program, he noted, featured Janeane Garofalo, the actress and Air America Radio personality who is active in liberal causes, and the former Representative Robert Barr, a conservative Republican from Georgia. 
 And he pointed to a recent ''Now'' report about the Veterans Administration, which suggested that the agency may not have the resources to help soldiers returning from the Persian Gulf or Afghanistan suffering from post-traumatic stress syndrome.
 ''I don't want somebody pointing to a story like that and saying, 'Oh, of course he's saying that. He's a Trotskyite,''' he said. ''I just want people to look at what we've found out about the V.A. and not have my voting behavior, or lack of it, entering into the discussion. That's the kind of journalism I do. It's not the kind of journalism that wins you many friends in high places.''
 Well, he has at least one admirer who used to work for the White House: Mr. Moyers. ''David is doing something no other broadcast does on Friday night -- real reporting of stories instead of just talking about the news,'' Mr. Moyers said. ''He's far more of a natural at this than I was, and he's way ahead of where I was at his age. If television journalism survives, he will be one of its leading lights.'' 
 Mr. Brancaccio recently learned that ''Now'' has been renewed through 2006, which means that its version of television journalism will survive for at least the next 18 months. After that, who knows? Uncertainty is the nature of television, particularly public television, particularly controversial public television.
 ''I've got to believe that whatever happens to us,'' Mr. Brancaccio said, ''that people will look back at 'Now With Bill Moyers' and 'Now' and say, 'Wasn't that a great moment in television news, when they were doing what they were supposed to be doing: Going out and finding important stories.' 
 ''It's a funny time in the world that it almost seems radical that we're doing this stuff.''

LENGTH: 726 words

BYLINE: By Margo Nash

 BODY:

The Dark Side of Paradise
 Never mind first acts in American life; F. Scott Fitzgerald and his wife, Zelda, are about to get their zillionth. 
 The tempestuous marriage of the Fitzgeralds -- perhaps literary America's favorite unhappy couple -- has been transformed into a musical that its producers, being producers, hope is headed for Broadway. ''Waiting for the Moon: An American Love Story'' is scheduled to have its world premiere in July at the Lenape Regional Performing Arts Center in Marlton. Frank Wildhorn, composer of ''The Scarlet Pimpernel'' and ''Jekyll&Hyde,'' wrote the music and Jack Murphy the book. ''Waiting for the Moon'' is scheduled to open July 20 and run through July 31. 
 ''This is the first time there has ever been a premiere like this in southern New Jersey,'' said Vincent Marini, the Lenape Center's artistic director. ''It's absolutely a new thing for down here.'' 
 As the Fitzgeralds look backward on their difficult life together, the musical will shift among Alabama, New York, Paris and Hollywood. ''One of the things that turned me on was that a lot of the show is from her point of view,'' Mr. Wildhorn said. ''She is the belle of the ball, the best the South has to offer. She falls under his shadow. They live on the edge. Somewhere along the way she has lost herself and struggles to find her own identity. It's given me wonderful themes.'' 
 Mr. Wildhorn has already been associated with several concerts at the Lenape Center, which is where he met Mr. Marini.
 ''Vince is so smart, such a good producer and a good guy,'' Mr. Wildhorn said. ''We became friends and talked about doing things.'' 
 Last summer, Mr. Marini produced a concert version of ''Jekyll&Hyde'' there that will go on tour nationwide this fall. 
 ''We will invite the world to Lenape to see it,'' Mr. Wildhorn said of the Fitzgerald project, noting that all of his musicals started out at regional theaters and gave him a crucial ''laboratory outside of New York.''
 He said he is proud to bring the new musical to the Lenape Center. ''The people there have been great to me,'' he said.

Virtually a Movie
 When John Belton watches a ''Star Wars'' movie, it makes him think about the future -- the future of the digital film.
 Mr. Belton, a professor of film and English at Rutgers, thinks he knows what that future holds and plans to write a book about digital cinema, using the time he bought by winning a Guggenheim Fellowship last month. 
 Digital cinema is leading film in two directions, Mr. Belton said: ''Fantasy films in utopian space,'' and an expansion of experimental and independent cinema.
 Though digital cinema has yet to take over the film industry, Mr. Belton, who has written five books about movies, believes that it will.
 ''I think the economic powers are looking for a direct connection from the studios to the home,'' he said. ''Film exhibitors will resist, but eventually movie theaters will be replaced by video on demand.''
 George Lucas led off the digital trend with his ''Star Wars'' movies, Mr. Belton said. Now more and more movies are using the technology. ''Sin City,'' the noir film released last month starring Bruce Willis, ''has that sort of digital look where the entire space veers toward some kind of abstract fantasy.''
 Technological change has its downside, he warned. ''Film has been around for 100 years or more, and if you found a film from 1905 and put it on any projector in the world, you would be able to play it,'' he said. ''Digital technology has been with us a shorter period of time and has run through different standards.'' Years from now it may be hard to screen old digital films, he said.
 And what about the quality of the digital image? ''I think that there is a psychological experience that is very unique to light being projected through film through silver haloid suspended in the emulsions,'' Mr. Belton said. ''There is a grain structure to the film that is random, little bits and pieces of information are stored on the grain. But the grain itself is naturally occurring, not a pixel.''
 In the end, ''it's going to be sad,'' Mr. Belton said. ''So much great material has been made on film, and the idea that somehow we are going to end up converting 'Citizen Kane' and 'Casablanca' to digital is sad. It's not as bad as colorization, but it's going to be a different experience.'' Margo Nash

LENGTH: 1697 words

HEADLINE: Across Iran, Nuclear Power Is a Matter of Pride

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

DATELINE: TEHRAN, May 28 

 BODY:
From nuclear negotiators to student dissidents, from bazaar merchants to turbaned mullahs, Iranians agree: the right to develop nuclear power is a point of national pride. 
 ''For a country to have nuclear energy means that it has made progress in all other fields as well, so other countries have to respect its technology,'' said Nilufar, 29, a graduate student in energy management at the prestigious Sharif Industrial University. Nilufar, covered in black so only her face was showing, agreed to be interviewed on such a delicate topic only if her family name was not used. 
 Ehsan Motaghi, a 26-year-old seminary student in Isfahan, cited a parable from Imam Ali, the Prophet Muhammad's son-in-law and the inspiration for the Shiite branch of Islam, which most Iranians follow. ''They can offer me everything from the earth and heaven, but in exchange if they want me to so much as take the food from an ant's mouth that is his right to eat, I won't do it,'' he said. ''Achieving the peaceful use of technology is really a matter of pride and we will not stop this for anything.'' 
 Such passions were echoed in two weeks of conversations with Iranians across all walks of life. Virtually all supported Iran's defying the West and moving ahead with its uranium enrichment program, which carries the threat of further United Nations sanctions. 
 This widespread sense of national pride complicates any attempt to persuade Iran's leaders to give up parts of the nuclear program, as European negotiators have been trying to prevail upon them to do in talks over the past few months, offering various incentives. 
 A monthlong United Nations conference on the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, which Iran has signed, ended Friday, having failed to address the kinds of loopholes that the Americans and Europeans fear Iran is using to pursue nuclear weapons under cover of developing nuclear power. 
 That issue aside, it is clear that Iran's attachment to nuclear development is rooted in its own tumultuous history. The Islamic republic is trying to use its nuclear program as a bargaining chip to end the varying degrees of international isolation it has been forced to endure since the Islamic revolution in 1979. 
 The nuclear standoff also echoes an older fight: Iran's colonial struggle to control its oil resources, which it eventually wrestled away from the British. Some reach further back, reflecting a desire to revive the glory of ancient Persia. Others want to claim Iran's future, to prove that the Islamic revolution can overcome its reputation for abysmal management.
 ''It is a symbolic thing for Iranians,'' said Mohammad Saeidi, the vice president for planning and international affairs at the Atomic Energy Organization of Iran. ''Our people are very clever, very smart and they want to use all the advanced technology in the world--nuclear technology, biotechnology, internet technology.''
 But for all the passion in the air, there are many nuances in Iranian positions, according to Iranian officials, scholars and foreign diplomats. In fact, they say, Iranian backing for nuclear development indicates neither automatic support for the government nor hostility to the United States. 
 Only a small group, mostly hard-core revolutionaries, wants Iran to resign from the treaty and try to develop nuclear weapons, they say. ''It would be 100 percent better to have nuclear weapons, but only to use them against anyone who tried to attack us,'' said Reza Jaedi, a 24-year-old interviewed in Isfahan who has little sympathy for the government. ''Iran should develop them as soon as possible.'' 
 It is rare to hear such views voiced in Iran, since they contradict the official line that Iran wants the technology only for peaceful means. 
 Another group opposes nuclear development as entirely too expensive, unnecessary given the vast oil or gas reserves and not worth the international political headache. In fact, say some scholars who have interviewed ordinary Iranians, some back off their support for nuclear development if they are told it might bring further economic hardship and international isolation to Iran. 
 But most Iranians, the experts say, fall into two other groups. One believes Iran should use nuclear technology for peaceful purposes. Another wants Iran to master the nuclear enrichment cycle both to avoid depending on foreign suppliers for nuclear fuel and to be able to move quickly to weapons development if Iran were threatened, either by Israel, the United States or a regional rival. That group sees nuclear power as an insurance policy against a forced change in the government. 
 Unquestionably most Iranians would like to find a way to end economic sanctions so the country could use its vast oil wealth -- an estimated $10 billion surplus this year -- to fix the country's infrastructure, among other ills. Their second-hand jets crash with alarming frequency, their cellphone network is so overburdened that practically every conversation is a torturous series of half-heard sentences, and investment in the prized oil industry is problematic.
 Some of the Iranians interviewed argued that having access to American technology would be worth abandoning the nuclear program, but many others say no economic incentives would be enough to persuade Iran to abandon its rights under the treaty. The surplus provides a cushion against outside pressure. 
 ''At this time, God wants us to make what we need!'' thundered Yousef Tabatabai, the Friday Prayer leader, in his sermon last week at the main mosque in Isfahan. ''Other countries now feel threatened because we have advanced in our technology.'' 
 If Iranians were asked whether the mullahs should have missiles, many would say no because that would help cement the power of a repressive government, foreign diplomats and scholars who have studied the issue say. 
 But if asked if Iran should master nuclear technology, most Iranians point out that it is the country's right under the nonproliferation treaty. (It is not hard to find Iranians who can refer directly to Article 4 of the treaty, which codifies signatories' right to develop nuclear power for peaceful purposes.) 
 ''Western countries are not recognizing Iran's legitimate right to use nuclear energy because of this government's hostile attitude toward the United States and its lack of legitimacy,'' said Mehdi Aminzadeh, one of the leaders of the student protest movement. ''The U.S. should not use the animosity it has toward our government to take away our rights as a people because any government will change sooner or later.'' 
 Government critics would like any deal to be tied to improved civil rights.
 In talks on Wednesday in Geneva, Iran and the European Union agreed to continue Iran's freeze on uranium enrichment, a step toward making nuclear fuel, for a few months while the Europeans develop proposals on cooperation in security, economics and other matters. On Thursday, the World Trade Organization agreed to accept Iran's application for membership, after United States dropped its decade-long opposition. 
 Many Iranians say the West should not worry about Iran developing nuclear missiles because Islam forbids such weapons. But Iran hid some of its nuclear preparations from the International Atomic Energy Agency for two decades -- including its enrichment of low levels of uranium in a Tehran suburb, prompting deep suspicions in Western states that Iran's goal is a weapons program. 
 The ruling mullahs are galled that the United States, which treated Iran under the shah as the natural leader of the region, blocks any such role for the current government. Nuclear technology might make them players again -- as might the bargaining to limit it. 
 Iran's capacity to produce electricity is more than 30,000 megawatts, mostly from oil-fired plants, but demand is expected to top out around 110,000 megawatts. That alone, along with uranium deposits in the central deserts, makes nuclear power viable in Iran, scientists say. There is no reason they should be forced to import fuel, which is one of the Western proposals to limit its nuclear capacity. 
 The officials all deny that Iran would try to develop weapons and say international inspectors would have full access. ''They can come and see for themselves, and they will find out that there is no room for suspicion,'' Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, the front-runner in the June 17 presidential election, said in an interview this week. ''I say we do not want them at all, and that means we do not want to be close to producing them.'' 
 Nuclear experts estimate that weapons development is still some years away, especially because Iran has yet to master the technology for uranium enrichment.
 Some Iranians worry that Western governments, in pressuring the government hard to abandon any nuclear development, will win the day for the hard-liners. ''Just asking Iran to stop enriching uranium is not going to work, and the alternative is much worse; the alternative is weapons,'' said Nasser Hadian, a political science professor. 
 The ultimate solution would be for the Europeans to work alongside the Iranians, ensuring that nothing is diverted into a weapons program, some Iranians argue. They say broken contracts for nuclear energy after the revolution also justify their drive for self-sufficiency. 
 But all that would be impossible without American approval, because it holds the licenses for most nuclear processes. Ali Salehi, a professor at Sharif University of Technology, notes that early in the Iran-Iraq war of 1980-1988 the Iranian military asked scientists at his university to develop mortars. The first few prototypes exploded, but eventually researchers mastered the metallurgy. So it went with radar and a host of other equipment that the Iranians could not buy. He expects that it will be the same with nuclear energy. 
 ''They're not as good as the ones that are built in the West, but we have acquired a lot of expertise and more than that we have acquired a lot of self-confidence,'' said Professor Salehi, a former Iranian ambassador to the International Atomic Energy Organization. ''Nuclear research is a natural extension of that.''
